Text

GLARING spring sunshine and a piercing east wind rioted out of doors , and here and there overflowing flower - baskets made startling patches of colour against the vague blue - grey of [the streets]276-the streets , but indoors , in [the tall London house]277-the tall london house , there was only a sickly , yellow twilight , for the orange - toned blinds were scrupulously drawn down . There was awe in [the passages]278-the passages , and hushed tones even in [the kitchen]279-the kitchen , as if [the dead]280-the dead could hear ! Some wreaths and crosses of wax - like , exotic flowers lay on the hall - table , filling [the passage]281-the passage with [their]282-their sensuous odour . [Friends calling to inquire]283-friends calling to inquire had left [them]282-their [there]284-there , but [they]282-their had not yet been taken up to [that darkened room]285-that darkened room where a marble figure — a figure which was strangely unlike [Professor Erle]123-professor erle — lay stretched , in an enduring silence , on the bed . [Downstairs]286-downstairs , in [the little study giving on [a meagre London yard]288-a meagre london yard]287-the little study giving on a meagre london yard , [a girl]289-a girl was bending over a desk . ‘ [You]1667-you will , [I]289-a girl know , be grieved to hear that [[my]289-a girl dear father]1668-my dear father passed suddenly away the night before last , ’[289-a girl] [she]289-a girl wrote , while a great nerve in [her]289-a girl forehead went tick , tick , tick . [The visitors who came all day long , leaving bits of paste - board]290-the visitors who came all day long , leaving bits of paste - board , spoke in low , inquisitive tones . When the bell rang , there were veiled whispers at the hall - door . ‘ So terrible — so sudden ! ’[290-the visitors who came all day long , leaving bits of paste - board] [Mary]124-mary could hear [them]290-the visitors who came all day long , leaving bits of paste - board inquire how [she]124-mary was keeping up ? And [Elizabeth]125-elizabeth 's answer : ‘ [Miss Erle]126-miss erle is as well as could be expected . ’[125-elizabeth] The trite , worn - out , foolish sentence almost made [her]124-mary laugh . All the stock phrases of condolence , all the mental trappings of woe , seemed to be ready - made for the ‘ sad occasion , ’[124-mary] like the crape skirts and cloaks which had been forwarded immediately from [the mourning establishment in [Regent Street]1-regent street]291-the mourning establishment in regent street . ‘ Yes , [I]124-mary am as well as could be expected , ’[124-mary] [she]124-mary thought , ‘ and [father]1669-father is dead . [Father]127-father is dead . ’[124-mary] And all the long afternoon [she]124-mary went on mechanically writing : ‘ [I]124-mary am sure [you]1670-you will be sorry when [I]124-mary tell [you]1670-you that [[my]124-mary dear father]1668-my dear father — ’[124-mary] on paper bordered with black an inch deep . How [he]292-his would have disliked that foolish ostentation of mourning ; it was contrary to the spirit of [his]292-his life . ‘ To - morrow , ’[124-mary] [she]124-mary said to [herself]124-mary , ‘ [I]124-mary must send for some note paper with a narrower edge . ’[124-mary] These letters were to be sent abroad . The English newspapers had sufficiently announced the death , for [Professor Erle]123-professor erle was perhaps [the best - known man of science of the day]293-the best - known man of science of the day . In [the little back room]294-the little back room [they]295-they had to light the lamp early , there was so much to do , so many details to arrange . The ceremony was to be as simple as might be ; above all , [no paid priest]296-no paid priest would stand at the grave to give ‘ hearty thanks ’[299-its spokesman] that [the great thinker]297-the great thinker had been ‘ delivered out of the miseries of [this sinful world]1672-this sinful world . ’[299-its spokesman] [The sinful world]298-the sinful world would have as [its spokesman]299-its spokesman [another famous professor , who had asked to be allowed to say a few words]300-another famous professor , who had asked to be allowed to say a few words . Then there were the newspapers . There was [the brisk , smartly - dressed young gentleman who came to do a leader for [a daily paper]302-a daily paper , and who proceeded to make a number of notes in shorthand , asking innumerable questions as [his]292-his omnivorous glance travelled rapidly round [the study]303-the study]301-the brisk , smartly - dressed young gentleman who came to do a leader for a daily paper , and who proceeded to make a number of notes in shorthand , asking innumerable questions as his omnivorous glance travelled rapidly round the study . [Another press - man]304-another press - man — [a small , apologetic man with greyish hair and a timid cough]305-a small , apologetic man with greyish hair and a timid cough — asked to see [the house for the Weekly Planet]306-the house for the weekly planet . [He]304-another press - man begged of [Elizabeth]125-elizabeth on [the hall steps]307-the hall steps , to tell [him]304-another press - man if [the Professor]308-the professor had said anything — anything particular , which would work up as [a leader]309-a leader , just at the last ? ‘ Oh ! [sir]1673-sir , ’[125-elizabeth] said [Elizabeth]125-elizabeth , ‘ did n't [you]1673-sir know ? [Master]1674-master did n't say anything . [He]1674-master just died in [his]1674-master sleep . ’[125-elizabeth] [The daughter]310-the daughter went about [her]310-the daughter tasks with a sense of detachment , of intense aloofness . ‘ [I]310-the daughter wonder if [I]310-the daughter really feel it ? ’[310-the daughter] [she]310-the daughter thought , ‘ and why [I]310-the daughter have never cried ? [I]310-the daughter should like to , but it is impossible ; [I]310-the daughter shall never , never cry again . ’[310-the daughter] It was as if Death , with [his]308-the professor cruel , searing wings had cauterised [her]310-the daughter very soul . Sometimes [she]310-the daughter pictured [herself]310-the daughter in [her]310-the daughter long crepe veil at the funeral , and heard in imagination [[her]310-the daughter friends]311-her friends murmuring pitying words , as [they]311-her friends all followed the coffin up the Highgate slope . [Alison Ives]128-alison , of course , would be with [her]310-the daughter ; [she]128-alison would stay by [her]310-the daughter , perhaps , and hold [her]310-the daughter hand . And probably [Vincent Hemming]129-vincent would be near . Yes , [he]129-vincent too would be [there]284-there . At dinner - time [she]310-the daughter had to sit down to table alone . [She]310-the daughter was hungry , and [she]310-the daughter ate , hardly knowing what was on [her]310-the daughter plate . Nothing happened as it does in tales and romances . In innumerable novels [she]310-the daughter had read how [the heroine]313-the heroine , in [a house of mourning]314-a house of mourning , lies on the bed for days and steadily refuses to eat . As for [Mary]124-mary , [a demon of unrest]315-a demon of unrest possessed [her]124-mary during that horrible week , and it was as if [she]124-mary could not eat nourishing food enough . [She]124-mary never stopped arranging , writing , adding up accounts . It was useless to try and read . Did [she]124-mary but take up a book , that dominant image in [her]124-mary mind — the image of a dear face turned to marble , with the cold , triumphant smile of eternity on its lips — shut out the sense of the words as [her]124-mary eyes travelled down the page . And the strange , unmistakable odour of death , mixed with the voluptuous scent of waxen hot - house flowers , hung , night and day , about the staircase . Towards the end of the week , there was more noise and bustle , and at last had come the morning when [the house]316-the house swarmed with [[undertakers]317-undertakers ' men]1675-undertakers ' men , and [Mary]124-mary and [[her]124-mary young brother Jimmie , who had arrived from [Winchester]2-winchester]1676-her young brother jimmie , who had arrived from winchester , sat with [a few old friends]1677-a few old friends in [the dining - room]1678-the dining - room , waiting for the signal to go . There was the shuffling of [men]1679-men 's feet , as [they]1679-men staggered down the narrow [London]3-london staircase with [their]1679-men heavy burden , and then [someone]1680-someone had made [the girl]1681-the girl swallow some sal volatile , and [she]1681-the girl was pushed gently into [the first mourning carriage]1682-the first mourning carriage , along with [[her]124-mary brother]1683-her brother . [They]1679-men had made [the boy]1684-the boy drink some of the sal volatile too , and [they]1679-men both felt strangely elated and highly strung . There were only [those two]1685-those two now , and [Mary]124-mary felt warmly drawn to [Jimmie]130-jimmie , as [they]1679-men sat side by side in [their]1679-men new black clothes , [the two chief personages in the ceremony of to - day]1686-the two chief personages in the ceremony of to - day . [She]124-mary even pretended not to hear when , [some gutter urchins]1687-some gutter urchins making complicated cartwheels as [their]1687-some gutter urchins contribution to the imposing procession , [Jimmie]130-jimmie , [boy]1688-boy - like , gave way to a furtive giggle . The drive to [Highgate]4-highgate seemed interminable , but at last , when [the long procession]1689-the long procession crept slowly up [the hill]1690-the hill , it was in a kind of stupor that [the girl]1681-the girl saw and heard what happened . There was , [she]1681-the girl remembered afterwards , a long line of [people , habited in black]1692-people , habited in black , awaiting [them]319-the people in silence inside [the cemetery]1693-the cemetery gate ; a tolling bell , neighing horses , and a penetrating scent of early lilac . Sunlight on [the paths]1694-the paths , on [the shining marble tombs]1695-the shining marble tombs , on the humble little mounds covered in plush - like grass ; then a moving mass of black , a yawning hole , the creaking of ropes , and the mellifluous voice of [the eminent professor]1696-the eminent professor , speaking [his]1696-the eminent professor oration over some upturned clay . ‘[317-undertakers] [England]5-england — [I]0-i may say [the world]318-the world — is mourning to day for [her]5-england illustrious son’—how [the people]319-the people pressed round the yawning gap , and pushed against the guelder rose - tree overhead , so that the flowers fell in a minute white shower on to the oaken coffin below—‘the world is mourning for [[her]5-england illustrious son]320-her illustrious son . Not that those tears will flow in vain , for they will moisten and fructify the precious tree of Truth , a tree which is evermore putting forth fresh branches and new fruits which are indispensable to the physical and moral evolution of [humanity]321-humanity . ’ In a neighbouring laburnum - bush , a thrush was swelling its brown throat with a joyous morning song . Athwart the pale sky dappled with fleecy clouds , the lilac bushes were burgeoning with waxen , pinkish blossoms . The very air throbbed with coming life . ‘[5-england] Nature , ’ continued [the orator]1697-the orator , in [his]1697-the orator measured , lecture - room tones , ‘[5-england] Nature , who works in inexorable ways , has taken to [herself]322-herself a life full of arduous toil , of epoch - making achievement , of immeasurable possibilities , but to what end , and for what purpose , is not given to [us]323-us , who stand to - day with full hearts and yearnings eye around [his]322-herself last resting - place , to know . ’ The sun was warm overhead , the scent of the pink may was strong in the nostrils ; a joyous twittering in an adjacent bush told of mating birds , of new life in the nests , of Nature rioting in an insolent triumph . [The orator]1697-the orator paused for an instant , coughed , and felt in [his]1697-the orator breast pocket for [his]1697-the orator notes . [He]1697-the orator was anxious , above all things , that [the reporters]1699-the reporters should not print a garbled version of [his]1697-the orator speech . Round the open grave pressed [the devotees of science]1700-the devotees of science , [the followers of the religion of humanity]1701-the followers of the religion of humanity ; [grey - skinned , anxious - looking men]1702-grey - skinned , anxious - looking men and [women , with lined foreheads and hair prematurely tinged with grey ; large heads with bulging foreheads , thin throats and sloping shoulders]1703-women , with lined foreheads and hair prematurely tinged with grey ; large heads with bulging foreheads , thin throats and sloping shoulders ; [the women with nervous , overworked worked faces]1704-the women with nervous , overworked worked faces , [the men with the pathetic , unrestful features of those who are sustained in a life of self - denial]1705-the men with the pathetic , unrestful features of those who are sustained in a life of self - denial by [their]1705-the men with the pathetic , unrestful features of those who are sustained in a life of self - denial ethical sense alone . The ceremony of to - day was a great moral demonstration . [All classes who think were represented]1706-all classes who think were represented . Side by side stood [a white - haired Radical Countess in simple half - mourning]1707-a white - haired radical countess in simple half - mourning and the spare form of [a Socialist working woman]1708-a socialist working woman , with red , ungloved wrists and an inspired look on [her]1708-a socialist working woman worn face . There , with [[her]1708-a socialist working woman mother]1709-her mother , [Lady Jane]131-lady jane , was [Alison Ives]128-alison . [Lady Jane]131-lady jane , who was impressionable , was already exhibiting a pocket - handkerchief , and not far off , [Mary]124-mary caught for one instant the brown , wistful eyes of [Vincent Hemming]129-vincent . The sun grew hotter and hotter overhead . [One or two of [the mourners]1711-the mourners]1710-one or two of the mourners began putting up umbrellas . The perfume of pink hawthorn became almost oppressive ; an early butterfly hovered over [a baby]1712-a baby 's grave planted with sweet - smelling flowers . A light breeze fluttered a laburnum - bush which hung over [a neighbouring marble tomb]1713-a neighbouring marble tomb , [a large , opulent , marble tomb , on which was cut in glittering gilt letters]1714-a large , opulent , marble tomb , on which was cut in glittering gilt letters : ‘[325-isolated men] Of such is [the Kingdom of Heaven]324-the kingdom of heaven . ’ And everywhere there was the whiteness of [graves]1715-graves . In ridges , in waves , in mounds , they stuck , tooth - like , from the fecund earth . They shone , in gleaming , distant lines , up to [the ridge of [the hill]1690-the hill]1716-the ridge of the hill ; [they]1711-the mourners crowded in serried battalions , down to [the cemetery]1693-the cemetery gates . [The speaker]1719-the speaker was concluding [his]1719-the speaker speech . ‘[325-isolated men] For though to [isolated men]325-isolated men , ’ [he]1719-the speaker said , raising [his]1719-the speaker voice so that [all who were on the edge of the crowd]1720-all who were on the edge of the crowd should hear , ‘[325-isolated men] it may be given here and there to scale the loftiest heights — ay , and ever new height rising upon height in [the great undiscovered country]326-the great undiscovered country which [we]327-we call [the realm of Science]328-the realm of science ; there , too , the Finite touches the Infinite , and must recognise what of tentativeness , what of inconclusiveness belongs to mere human effort . Here , on a sudden , the dark , impenetrable curtain , which none may draw aside , envelops [us]327-we ; here [we]327-we know not whether all ends with this [[our]327-we last prison house]329-our last prison house , or if to [us]327-we may be opened out yet further cycles of aspiring activity . ’ In the silence which followed there was heard one long , sweet , penetrating bird - call . [One of [the chief mourners]1722-the chief mourners]1721-one of the chief mourners , [the boy Jimmie]1723-the boy jimmie , was sobbing loudly when [the professor]308-the professor 's voice stopped , and with something gripping at [her]1721-one of the chief mourners throat , [the sister]1725-the sister led [him]1723-the boy jimmie away . [She]1725-the sister reproached [herself]1725-the sister with having brought [him]1723-the boy jimmie ; [the young]1726-the young , [she]1725-the sister thought , should not know what sorrow is . [The two spare , black - clad figures]1727-the two spare , black - clad figures stepped aside up [the hill]1690-the hill . Out yonder , at [their]1727-the two spare , black - clad figures feet , the dun - colour of [the buildings]1729-the buildings lost in the murkiness of the horizon line , [London]3-london was spread out . Here and there a dome , a spire loomed out of the dim bluish - grey panorama . A warm haze hung over [the great city]1730-the great city ; here and there a faint fringe of tree - tops told of [a placid park]1731-a placid park ; now and again the shrill whistle of an engine , blown northward by the wind , spoke of the bustle of journeys , of the turmoil of [railway - stations]1732-railway - stations , of partings , of arrivals , of the change and travail of human life , of [the strangers who come]1733-the strangers who come , of [the failures who must go]1734-the failures who must go . ‘[130-jimmie] [Jim]130-jimmie , ’ said [the girl]1681-the girl suddenly , taking [the boy]1684-the boy by the arm , ‘[130-jimmie] there 's [London]3-london ! [We]330-we 're going to make it listen to [us]330-we , [you]1684-the boy and [I.]1681-the girl [We]330-we 're[130-jimmie] not going to be afraid of it — just because it 's big , and brutal , and strong . ’ ‘[130-jimmie] N — no , [dearest]331-dearest , ’ said [the boy]1684-the boy , turning up a pretty , sensitive face , and a pink nose all smeared with tears . ‘[130-jimmie] Of course not . ’ [The black crowd yonder]1738-the black crowd yonder was swaying , separating , and disintegrating itself into separate sable dots which were now seen descending the paths to [the cemetery]1693-the cemetery - gate . And slowly , [they]330-we too stepped down [the gravel path]1740-the gravel path . [They]330-we came [home]1741-home to [a house]1742-a house that was empty and orderly again ; [a house in which [his]1684-the boy door stood open , the pale light of a spring afternoon filling [the desolate room]1744-the desolate room]1743-a house in which his door stood open , the pale light of a spring afternoon filling the desolate room . The blinds were pulled up , and [downstairs]286-downstairs , in [the kitchen]279-the kitchen , [the servants]1747-the servants had begun to talk and laugh . Towards dusk , [Jimmie]130-jimmie got engrossed in a new book of adventures , but [the girl]1681-the girl , restless still , wandered about [the house]316-the house in [her]1681-the girl black gown looking at everything with strange eyes . Something terrible , unforeseen had happened which altered [her]1681-the girl whole life . Towards [the boy]1684-the boy poring over the picture - book [she]1681-the girl felt much of [a mother]1751-a mother 's feelings ; it behoved [her]1681-the girl to look after [him]1684-the boy now that [[his]1684-the boy father]1752-his father was gone . How long the time seemed — would the interminable day never end ? There must be lots for [her]1681-the girl to do . And casting about in [her]1681-the girl mind , [she]1681-the girl remembered that this was the day on which [she]1681-the girl always gave out the groceries from [[her]1681-the girl store cupboard]1753-her store cupboard ; there was [the seamstress]1754-the seamstress to pay , too , who was altering a black dress for [her]1681-the girl up - stairs . So [Mary]124-mary dragged [herself]124-mary down to [the kitchens]1755-the kitchens and presently to [the top of [the house]316-the house]1756-the top of the house . It would be nice of [her]124-mary , [she]124-mary thought , to go in and speak to [the woman who was sewing alone]1758-the woman who was sewing alone . It was sad for [a young woman]1759-a young woman to be alone . The pale , pinkish light of a spring evening fell on [a drab - complexioned girl]1760-a drab - complexioned girl , whose fat hand moved , as [she]1760-a drab - complexioned girl sewed , with the regularity of a machine . Now the needle was thrust in the fold of black stuff , and the light fell on [her]1760-a drab - complexioned girl ill - cut nails ; now the hand was aloft , in the semi- obscurity ; it was all tame , monotonous and regular as a clock . [She]1760-a drab - complexioned girl was [a docile , humble , uncomplaining creature , who suggested [inevitably some patient domestic animal]1762-inevitably some patient domestic animal]1761-a docile , humble , uncomplaining creature , who suggested inevitably some patient domestic animal . [Her]1760-a drab - complexioned girl features , rubbed out and effaced with generations of servility , spoke of the small mendacities of [the women of the lower classes]1763-the women of the lower classes , of [the women who live on ministering to the caprices of the well - to - do]1764-the women who live on ministering to the caprices of the well - to - do . To - day it would seem [she]1760-a drab - complexioned girl had assumed an appropriately dolorous expression . It sometimes soothed [Mary]124-mary to stitch . Taking up a strip of black merino , [she]124-mary began to hem . [The seamstress]1754-the seamstress 's hand continued to move with docile regularity , and , as [Mary]124-mary looked at [her]1760-a drab - complexioned girl , [she]124-mary was curiously reminded of [many women [she]124-mary had seen]1766-many women she had seen : [ladies]1767-ladies , [mothers of large families , who sat and sewed with just such an expression of unquestioning resignation]1768-mothers of large families , who sat and sewed with just such an expression of unquestioning resignation . The clicking sound of the needle , the swish of the drawn - out thread , the heavy breathing of [the work - woman]1769-the work - woman , all added to the impression . Yes , [they]1766-many women she had seen too were content to exist subserviently , depending always on [someone else]1770-someone else , using the old feminine stratagems , the well - worn feminine subterfuges , to gain [their]1766-many women she had seen end . The woman who sews is eternally the same . The light began to fail now ; very soon it would be dark . [Mary]124-mary threw down [her]124-mary work with an impatient gesture , and , in the grey twilight , an immense pity seized [her]124-mary for [the patient figure bending , near the window]1771-the patient figure bending , near the window , over [her]124-mary foolish strips of flounces , the figure of [the woman]1772-the woman at [her]124-mary monotonous toil . THE life of [Mary Erle]124-mary , like that of [many another woman in the end of the nineteenth century]1773-many another woman in the end of the nineteenth century , had been more or less in the nature of an experiment . Born too late for the simple days of the fifties , when all it behoved [a young girl]1774-a young girl to do was to mind [her]1774-a young girl account - book , read [her]1774-a young girl Tennyson , show a proper enthusiasm for fancy - work stitches , and finally , with many blushes , accept the hand of [the first young man who desired to pay taxes and to fulfil the duties of a loyal British subject]1775-the first young man who desired to pay taxes and to fulfil the duties of a loyal british subject ( and [the young man]1776-the young man , it must be remembered , in the middle of this century , actually did both ) , [Mary]124-mary was yet too soon for the time when [parents]1777-parents begin to take [their]1777-parents responsibilities seriously , and when [the girl]1681-the girl is sometimes as carefully prepared , as thoroughly equipped , as [[her]1681-the girl brother]1683-her brother for the fight of life . [A garden full of flowers]1780-a garden full of flowers , [a house full of books , scraps of travel]1781-a house full of books , scraps of travel : these things were [her]1681-the girl education . Out of the years [she]1681-the girl could pick scenes and figures which typified [her]1681-the girl bringing - up . There was [the plain , self - contained , and not too clean baby]1782-the plain , self - contained , and not too clean baby . [A child who was always grubbing in a garden]1783-a child who was always grubbing in a garden , for [it]1783-a child who was always grubbing in a garden lived then in [a house in [St. John 's Wood]6-st. john 's wood]1784-a house in st. john 's wood ; [a child who was devoted to animals and insects , who was on intimate terms with the many - legged wood - lice , which curled themselves up with all haste into complete balls]1785-a child who was devoted to animals and insects , who was on intimate terms with the many - legged wood - lice , which curled themselves up with all haste into complete balls when [she]1681-the girl touched them ; [a child for whom snails and black - beetles had no terrors , and who had much to say to the green , hairy caterpillars which hung about the pear tree]1786-a child for whom snails and black - beetles had no terrors , and who had much to say to the green , hairy caterpillars which hung about the pear tree . There was [a huge , fluffy , black cat]1787-a huge , fluffy , black cat , too , which represented , perhaps , [the child]1788-the child 's primitive idea of [a deity]1789-a deity ; for , though [she]1681-the girl adored it , the adoration was leavened with a wholesome awe , a feeling which was not unconnected with certain unmerited chastisements in the shape of scratches on [her]1681-the girl fat , bare legs . More often , to be sure , the black cat was amiable , and even allowed [itself]1787-a huge , fluffy , black cat to be carried up to bed , with its hind legs straying out helplessly from under [the child]1788-the child 's arm , to be presently concealed with all haste and caution under the white sheets and blankets , from whence its sharp - pointed ears and wide black cheeks arose with the most exquisitely mirth - provoking effect . With what inscrutable amber eyes did the black cat gaze for hours into [hers]1681-the girl ! how it imposed on [her]1681-the girl babyish imagination with [its]1787-a huge , fluffy , black cat self - contained , majestic manners , its air of detachment from the vain shows of [the world]318-the world ! [The man with the kind smile]1792-the man with the kind smile , whom [the child]1788-the child called ‘[1669-father] [father]1669-father , ’ used to laugh at [her]1681-the girl adoration , tell [her]1681-the girl [she]1681-the girl was [a little Egyptian]1794-a little egyptian , and called the cat ‘[1669-father] Pasht . ’ [She]1681-the girl thought it a funny name , and not being altogether sure [the black cat]1795-the black cat would approve of it , generally addressed [it]1795-the black cat as ‘[333-you] [you]333-you . ’ And the cat would sit on long summer afternoons on the grass under the pear tree , or on foggy autumn days on a stool by the fireside , with paws neatly tucked away , its neck - ruff fluffed out , purring benignly in response to [her]1681-the girl confidences . Indeed , in looking back , the first tragedy of [the child]1788-the child 's life was the death of the black cat . [It]1787-a huge , fluffy , black cat lay , one sultry July day , under a laurel bush in [the garden]1797-the garden , with glazed eyes which gave no signs of life . All morning and all afternoon [the child]1788-the child sat there and fanned the flies away , until [her]1788-the child idol was stiff , and then a hole was hastily dug , and the black cat was thrust out of sight . And never any more , in the warm summer afternoons , did a soft , furry thing go sailing , tail in air , over the close - cropped lawn ; nor , on winter evenings , was a rhythmical purring to be heard hard by the tall fender which guarded the nursery fire . It was the first great void ; the first heartache had come . [A strange , indolent child , whose little hands were usually thrust beneath [her]1788-the child pinafore when [anyone]1800-anyone spoke to [her]1788-the child]1799-a strange , indolent child , whose little hands were usually thrust beneath her pinafore when anyone spoke to her ; for surely [she]1788-the child could not be always washing [herself]1788-the child , and to be on really intimate terms with insects and things , one can not , like [grown - up people]1801-grown - up people , be always thinking of [one]1802-one 's nails . [She]1788-the child usually , too , concealed a small piece of putty about [[her]1788-the child person]1803-her person — an unpardonable sin , this , in the eyes of [mother]1804-mother and [nurse]1805-nurse — for putty is useful in a thousand ways , and is , besides , so thrillingly delicious to feel surreptitiously in the recesses of one 's pocket . At this time [the child]1788-the child held [the whole race of dolls]1807-the whole race of dolls in high scorn . [They]1807-the whole race of dolls were [a foolish , over - dressed , uninteresting tribe , with manifestly absurd cheeks and eye - lashes]1808-a foolish , over - dressed , uninteresting tribe , with manifestly absurd cheeks and eye - lashes , and with a simper which was as artificial as that of [the ladies in chignons and flounces who came to call at the house of an afternoon]1809-the ladies in chignons and flounces who came to call at the house of an afternoon . [She]1788-the child , on [her]1788-the child part , was all for the violent delights of miniature guns and real gunpowder , the toilsome construction of [fleets of wooden boats]1810-fleets of wooden boats with the aid of a blunt knife and a plank of wood ; fleets which were set a - sail , with flying pennants , on the cistern hard by [the kitchen]279-the kitchen . There were [boy neighbours]1812-boy neighbours who aided and abetted [her]1788-the child in these delights , and great naval battles would come off between the Dutch and English fleets in the [kitchen cistern]1813-kitchen cistern , in which sometimes [Van Tromp]132-van tromp , and sometimes [Blake]133-blake , emerged victorious . [The child]1788-the child , perhaps , did not take [her]1788-the child patriotism seriously , as [the boys]1815-the boys did ; [she]1788-the child was content to be [Van Tromp]132-van tromp , since [they]1815-the boys insisted on being [Blake]133-blake and [Monk]134-monk . All that was of vital importance was that a fight of some sort should come off . [The mother]1816-the mother sank early out of ken . First [they]1815-the boys said that [she]1816-the mother was poorly , and had gone to [Italy]7-italy , and then [they]1815-the boys said that [she]1816-the mother was very ill , and afterwards that [she]1816-the mother was in [heaven]1817-heaven ; so that for a long time [the child]1788-the child used to think vaguely , as [she]1788-the child sat in [the summer - house]1819-the summer - house with pursed - up lips and knitted brows , notching and slicing at [[her]1816-the mother ships]1820-her ships , that [Italy]7-italy and [heaven]1817-heaven were perhaps [the same place]1822-the same place . [Nurse]135-nurse said that [[her]1788-the child mummy]1823-her mummy was [an angel]1824-an angel now ; but , in all the picture - books , [angels]1825-angels had long , smooth hair , wore a kind of night - gown , and had enormous , folding wings . [The child]1788-the child could not picture [[her]1788-the child mother]1709-her mother looking like that ; [she]1788-the child always remembered [her]1709-her mother in many flounces , with a headache ; and certainly , no , certainly , [mummy]1828-mummy never had any wings out of [her]1828-mummy back . [The child]1788-the child could recollect that , some little time before [[her]1788-the child mother]1709-her mother went to [Italy]7-italy , [they]1831-they took [her]1788-the child [upstairs]1832-upstairs one day and showed [her]1788-the child [a baby]1712-a baby , with a red , crinkled face , lying in an over - trimmed cradle . [She]1788-the child did not care for [babies]1834-babies , [she]1788-the child would rather have had a nice , new , fluffy kitten to replace the old black cat ; but when [they]1831-they told [her]1788-the child it was [a little brother]1835-a little brother , of course that altered matters . [She]1788-the child was sorry [[her]1788-the child brother]1683-her brother should be so small , so fretful , and so red in the face ; [she]1788-the child would rather have had [him]1683-her brother the same size as [herself]1788-the child , so that [he]1683-her brother could have been [Van Tromp]132-van tromp for once , and [she]1788-the child the victorious [Blake]133-blake ; but still , any sort or size of [brother]1837-brother was better than none . Although , in a year or so , [the baby]1838-the baby developed into something suspiciously like a doll , with [his]1683-her brother fat , pink cheeks , [his]1683-her brother round , china - blue eyes , [his]1683-her brother dump of a nose , and [his]1683-her brother entire absence of chin , still , [he]1683-her brother was far more entertaining than [that simpering and foolish tribe]1839-that simpering and foolish tribe . [Baby Jim]130-jimmie 's pink toes could kick ; [his]1683-her brother little fist , with the creases of fat at the wrist , could hit out ; there were warlike possibilities in [him]1683-her brother . In a word , [Baby Jim]130-jimmie was alive . At ten years old [the girl]1681-the girl began to have strange fits of vanity . There were little shoes and frocks which [she]1681-the girl held in high favour , and others which nothing would induce [her]1681-the girl to put on . To wear a pinafore , now , was a bitter humiliation , and about this period [she]1681-the girl had the most definite theories about the dressing of hair . The discussion on coiffures usually took place in [her]1681-the girl bath , when [a small , slippery person covered in soap - suds]1841-a small , slippery person covered in soap - suds was to be heard arguing with [[her]1681-the girl nurse]1842-her nurse — an argument which was not unusually enforced by physical violence — on the superior attractions of crimped to curled locks . At ten years old — [she]1681-the girl was of opinion — [a person]1843-a person was grown up , or at least as old as [any one]1844-any one need be . Why , [big , tall men , with long beards and spectacles]1845-big , tall men , with long beards and spectacles , who came to see [[her]1681-the girl father]1846-her father , would bend down and ask [her]1681-the girl gravely if [she]1681-the girl would be [[their]1845-big , tall men , with long beards and spectacles little wife]1847-their little wife ? [The child]1788-the child had been to more than one wedding , and [she]1681-the girl was aware that [a wife]1849-a wife was [a person who began by wearing a beautiful white satin train , with white flowers and a veil]1850-a person who began by wearing a beautiful white satin train , with white flowers and a veil ; [a person who was as imposing as that angel which [nurse]1805-nurse said [[her]1681-the girl mother]1709-her mother had become , although [she]1681-the girl had not , of course , any wings]1851-a person who was as imposing as that angel which nurse said her mother had become , although she had not , of course , any wings . [The child]1788-the child was not sure whether [she]1788-the child would best like to be [a bride]1855-a bride or [an angel]1824-an angel . The latter , it was true , had the additional attraction of a golden halo ; but [she]1681-the girl thought , probably , that matters might be compromised , and that [she]1681-the girl could be [a wife]1849-a wife and have a halo , too . The scene shifts now , for [they]1845-big , tall men , with long beards and spectacles had moved to [another quarter of [London]3-london]1858-another quarter of london , and the change made a vast difference in [the child]1788-the child 's tastes and habits . There was no cropped lawn now , where the pear tree made long shadows on summer afternoons , where [she]1681-the girl had a personal interest in [a plot of ground of [her]1681-the girl own]1860-a plot of ground of her own , and at least a bowing acquaintance with a whole host of fussy bumble - bees , gay yellow butterflies , furry caterpillars , and lazy snails . The firing off of toy guns was erased from the list of possible amusements . [The house]316-the house was [a tall one , in [a street]1866-a street in [town]1867-town]1865-a tall one , in a street in town , and [rural delights]1868-rural delights were represented by [a square yard at the back , which was haunted by stray , attenuated cats , and in which grew a solitary , stunted sycamore]1869-a square yard at the back , which was haunted by stray , attenuated cats , and in which grew a solitary , stunted sycamore . [She]1681-the girl had only to pick out [her]1681-the girl volume . It was a revelation in the possibilities of life . Looking back now , it must be owned that [she]1681-the girl led an odd life . [The man with the kind smile]1792-the man with the kind smile was fond of [[his]1792-the man with the kind smile little daughter]1873-his little daughter , but [he]1792-the man with the kind smile was always at work , either at experiments in [[his]1792-the man with the kind smile laboratory]1874-his laboratory or bending over [his]1792-the man with the kind smile desk in [the study]303-the study . One night [[her]1681-the girl father]1846-her father took [her]1681-the girl to [the theatre]1878-the theatre for the first time . [A famous actress]1879-a famous actress , [an old friend]1880-an old friend , was giving [Antony]136-antony and [Cleopatra]137-cleopatra , and [they]1881-they went first behind the scenes . [They]1881-they walked across a bare , lofty , cavern - like place , with dusty wooden boards , which sloped upwards , and [the child]1788-the child was lifted up to peep through a little hole in a red velvet curtain , and through it [she]1681-the girl saw a large horse - shoe with quantities of [people]1883-people chattering as [they]1881-they waited . Unfortunately , [the stout lady]1890-the stout lady looked fatter than ever when seen close , but there were so many amusing things about — a wig with long plaits , several serpent bracelets , a diadem , and a beautiful golden girdle set with emeralds as big as pheasants '[333-you] eggs . [The child]1788-the child was incorrigibly idle . And [all these people]352-all these people were real to [the child]1788-the child , much more real than [the people [she]1788-the child saw when [she]1788-the child went out to tea - parties in [her]1788-the child best frock and sash]354-the people she saw when she went out to tea - parties in her best frock and sash . And , later on , there is [the rather plain girl of fourteen]357-the rather plain girl of fourteen , with somewhat inscrutable eyes , and a seriousness which would have been portentous were it not laughable . [The girl]1681-the girl had much to occupy [her]1681-the girl mind . [She]1681-the girl began to understand something of life now . It was no longer a kind of coloured picture - book , made to catch the eye and amuse an idle half - hour . The pictures meant a great deal more than that . There were dreadful things , sad things , horrible things behind . Things that [the girl]1681-the girl could only guess at , but which were there , [she]1681-the girl was sure , all the same . [The world]318-the world , [she]1681-the girl could see from [her]1681-the girl books and newspapers , was full of injustice . There was the great wrong which had been done some eighteen hundred years ago , when the most beautiful life that was ever lived had come to a shameful end . [The girl]1681-the girl was always reading that moving story ; the Old Testament , with its revengeful , Jewish Deity , did not appeal to [her]1681-the girl at all . The poignant tragedy enacted at [Jerusalem]9-jerusalem ate into [her]1681-the girl heart , and [this child of fourteen]362-this child of fourteen felt [herself]1681-the girl burdened with the reproach which that senseless crime has left on [humanity]321-humanity for well - nigh two thousand years . Yes , those were serious days . Once in [her]1681-the girl teens , [she]1681-the girl had to make up [her]1681-the girl mind on many subjects . There were the questions of marriage , of maternity , of education . [The girl]1681-the girl had learned French by now , and the chance fingering of a small , last - century volume made [her]1681-the girl approach those supremely feminine subjects under the somewhat insecure guidance of [Jean Jacques Rousseau]142-jean jacques rousseau . [She]1681-the girl imbibed , indeed , [the Swiss philosopher]365-the swiss philosopher 's diatribes on virtue before [she]1681-the girl had comprehended what civilised mankind stigmatises as vice . [Emile]143-emile : ou , de l'Education was wearily , conscientiously toiled through for the sake of posterity . Le Contrat Social was a work which it behoved [a person of fourteen]366-a person of fourteen — [a person who wished to understand the scheme of civilisation]367-a person who wished to understand the scheme of civilisation — to know . Strange , anxious days , passed in the twilight of ignorance , groping among the vain shadows with which man in [his]368-his wisdom has elected to surround [the future mothers of the race]369-the future mothers of the race . It was not , of course , till years afterwards , that [Mary]124-mary became conscious of the fine irony of the fact that [man]370-man — the superior intelligence — should take [[his]370-man future companion]371-his future companion , shut [her]371-his future companion within four walls , fill that dimly - lighted interior with images of facts and emotions which do not exist , and then , pushing [her]371-his future companion suddenly into the blinding glare of real life , should be amazed when [he]370-man finds that [his]370-man exquisite care of [her]371-his future companion ethical sense has stultified [her]371-his future companion brain . [The girl]1681-the girl was reading [David Copperfield]144-david copperfield when [she]1681-the girl descended one day , with knitted brows , to [the room where [[her]1681-the girl governess]374-her governess]373-the room where her governess was laboriously copying in water - colours a lithographed bunch of roses . ‘ What is [a lost woman]1891-a lost woman really , [Miss Brown]145-miss brown ? ’[1681-the girl] demanded [the girl]1681-the girl , with [her]1681-the girl tense look . ‘ [Dickens]146-dickens says that [little Em'ly]147-little em'ly is [a lost woman]1891-a lost woman , because [she]147-little em'ly goes to [Italy]7-italy with that [Mr. Steerforth]148-mr. steerforth . Was [Mr. Steerforth]148-mr. steerforth [a lost man]1893-a lost man , too ? ’[1681-the girl] LOOKING back , across the vague , misty years , the egotism , the ferocious egotism , of [the young girl]376-the young girl appears well - nigh incredible . At eighteen , [she]376-the young girl , with [her]376-the young girl fluffy hair and [her]376-the young girl white shoulders , is the most important thing in [[her]376-the young girl little world]377-her little world . There is the day [she]376-the young girl first discovers [she]376-the young girl has a throat with fine lines ; the secret delight with which [she]376-the young girl hears [an artist]378-an artist tell [her]376-the young girl that the movements of [her]376-the young girl body are graceful . Does black , or blue , or white become [her]376-the young girl best ? It is never too late , and [she]376-the young girl is never too tired , when [she]376-the young girl comes back from a ball , to light all the candles again in [[her]376-the young girl bedroom]379-her bedroom and examine [herself]376-the young girl critically , anxiously , in the glass . There is a little pink spot of excitement on each cheek ; [her]376-the young girl hair is ruffled . [She]376-the young girl looks pretty , [she]376-the young girl has been happy to - night . [Some one]335-some one — no matter who — has told [her]376-the young girl [she]376-the young girl looks charming . There is the desire of [the young girl]376-the young girl to coquet , to play with , to torture , when [she]376-the young girl first learns the all - powerful influence which [she]376-the young girl possesses by the primitive fact of [her]376-the young girl sex . With all the arrogance which belongs to personal purity , [she]376-the young girl stands on [her]376-the young girl little pedestal and looks down on [mankind]382-mankind with a somewhat condescending smile . [She]376-the young girl is — and [she]376-the young girl feels it instinctively — a thing apart , a kind of forced plant , a product of civilisation . At present [the ball - room]383-the ball - room , with [its]383-the ball - room artificial atmosphere , [its]383-the ball - room fleeting devotions , its graceful mockery of real life , is the scene of [her]376-the young girl little triumphs . The eyes of [all men]384-all men — young and old alike — follow [the girl]1681-the girl approvingly , wistfully , as [she]376-the young girl ascends the staircase , [her]376-the young girl full heart beating against [her]376-the young girl slim satin bodice , the clear , peachlike cheeks pink with excitement , [her]376-the young girl swimming eyes raised invitingly to [some favourite partner]386-some favourite partner , or dropped as [she]376-the young girl passes [a man [she]376-the young girl wishes to avoid]387-a man she wishes to avoid . At the door [her]376-the young girl slender white arms and shoulders disappear in a circle of black coats ; the programme is scrawled all over ; [she]376-the young girl notes exultantly that [one or two men]388-one or two men are scowling at [each other]389-each other , and that [she]376-the young girl has no dance to give [some one who has joined [the group]391-the group too late]390-some one who has joined the group too late . It is [the woman]1772-the woman 's first taste of power . There is , too , the joie de vivre , the delight of [the young animal at play]393-the young animal at play , the imperious will - to - live of [a being in perfect health]394-a being in perfect health . [The girl]1681-the girl must dance till [her]1681-the girl feet ache horribly , [the room]396-the room swings round , and the pink dawn comes creeping in behind the drawn blinds ; but still [she]1681-the girl must go on till that music stops , the swaying , voluptuous heartrending music which draws [her]1681-the girl feet round and round . The violins , with their navrant tones , the human , dolorous strains of the cornets , the brilliant , metallic , artificial sounds of the piano , all act powerfully on [the young girl]376-the young girl 's nervous system . Then come [the stifling crowded supper - room]398-the stifling crowded supper - room , with [its]398-the stifling crowded supper - room indigestible food and sweet champagne ; [the young men who move nearer and look at [her]1681-the girl with strange eyes , after [they]399-the young men who move nearer and look at her with strange eyes , after they have eaten and drunk have eaten and drunk]399-the young men who move nearer and look at her with strange eyes , after they have eaten and drunk . It is all new and intoxicating , and a little frightening ; but it is life , or the nearest approach to it that [a young girl , gently nurtured and carefully looked after]400-a young girl , gently nurtured and carefully looked after , can possibly know . Admiration , at this period , is the very breath of [her]1681-the girl nostrils . No matter from whom , no matter when or where . A smile , seen like a flash , on a face in [a passing hansom]401-a passing hansom ; the ill - bred pertinacity of a raised lorgnette at [a theatre]402-a theatre ; the dubious gaze of men about [town]1867-town , leaning against [ball - room]404-ball - room doors — nothing offends [her]1681-the girl . It is simply incense burnt at the feet of [her]1681-the girl youth . But at last , out of [the vague crowd of black coats and wistful eyes]405-the vague crowd of black coats and wistful eyes , [the first lover]406-the first lover emerges . It is a little difficult to recall [his]406-the first lover face , after all these years . Looking back dispassionately , [he]406-the first lover seems to have been very like [all the others]407-all the others , only that [he]406-the first lover made [her]1681-the girl suffer , while [the others]408-the others , perhaps , suffered a little for [her]1681-the girl sake . There were the horrible half - hours of torture when [she]1681-the girl waited , in [some crowded party]409-some crowded party , for [his]406-the first lover sleek head and [his]406-the first lover somewhat foolish smile to appear in the door - way ; the blank , empty days when there was no letter ; the shamefully sweet , the incredible surrender to the first tentative embrace , a surrender which tortured [her]1681-the girl night and day , and then the joy , the supreme joy , of knowing , for certain , that [he]406-the first lover cared . It is all a little remote , now , but the beautiful secret was hugged like a very treasure . [He]406-the first lover was young , [he]406-the first lover was poor , there were difficulties of every sort to contend with , and finally there was a parting , one warm , windy night in November . It was a Sunday , about seven o'clock , and through the window , which was ajar in [the drawing - room where [they]411-they stood]410-the drawing - room where they stood , came the sound of a tolling bell . It was only [a neighbouring church]412-a neighbouring church summoning [pious folk to evening service]413-pious folk to evening service , but it sounded like a knell . It was a well - nigh hopeless affair , and all that [they]411-they could do was to promise to write to [each other]389-each other . For some weeks [the girl]1681-the girl watched , in the column of [the shipping intelligence]416-the shipping intelligence , the eastward progress of [a Peninsular and Oriental steamer]417-a peninsular and oriental steamer on [its]417-a peninsular and oriental steamer way to [Australia]10-australia , and after that , on the mornings when the mail came in , [she]1681-the girl would stand with [her]1681-the girl heart in [her]1681-the girl mouth , and [her]1681-the girl hand on the knob of the dining - room door , afraid to go in and find that no foreign envelope lay beside [her]1681-the girl plate . For some months , to be sure , the letters nearly always lay there , but gradually they got rarer and rarer , and one day [she]1681-the girl told [herself]1681-the girl finally that [she]1681-the girl need not expect any more . Torture is not made more bearable by being slowly applied . During the months in which those letters from [Australia]10-australia grew rarer , [the girl]1681-the girl understood for the first time the helplessness , the intolerable burden which society has laid on [her]1681-the girl sex . All things must be endured with a polite smile . Had [she]1681-the girl been [a boy]419-a boy , [she]1681-the girl was aware that [she]1681-the girl might have made an effort to break the maddening silence ; have stifled [her]1681-the girl sorrow with dissipation , with travel or hard work . As it was , the trivial round of civilised feminine existence made [her]1681-the girl , in those days , almost [an automaton]420-an automaton . [One]1802-one looks back , with wonder , at the courage of [the girl]1681-the girl . To find a smile with which to face [[her]1681-the girl father]1846-her father at the dinner table ; to take a sisterly interest in [Jim]130-jimmie 's exploits at [school]424-school ; to show due surprise each time [[her]1681-the girl brother]1683-her brother announced the arrival of a new batch of rabbits ; and a partisan 's joy in the licking which [Smith minor]149-smith minor had administered to [Jones major]426-jones major — these were the immediate duties which lay before [her]1681-the girl . Not feeling strong just now , [the girl]1681-the girl gave up going to balls ; [they]428-they reminded [her]1681-the girl too much of that episode which [she]1681-the girl wished to forget ; and now the prospect that opened out before [her]1681-the girl was a vista of years full of scientific soirées where [one]1802-one walked down [long sparsely - peopled rooms]430-long sparsely - peopled rooms and looked through microscopes at things which wriggled and squirmed . Sometimes [the girl]1681-the girl felt strangely like one of [those much - observed bacilli]432-those much - observed bacilli ; [the daughter of [a scientist]434-a scientist]433-the daughter of a scientist , [she]1681-the girl knew well enough that [her]1681-the girl little troubles had about as much importance as theirs in relation to [the vast universe]435-the vast universe . Yet there [she]1681-the girl was , fixed down under [her]1681-the girl little glass case , while [the world]318-the world kept a coldly observant eye upon [her]1681-the girl . Ah , the torture of [the young]1726-the young — [the young who are always unhappy , and whose little lives are continually coming to a full stop , with chapters that cease bluntly , brutally , without reason and without explanation]438-the young who are always unhappy , and whose little lives are continually coming to a full stop , with chapters that cease bluntly , brutally , without reason and without explanation . That [she]1681-the girl was thrown aside , dropped overboard , as it were , in the terrific battle for existence mattered nothing to [the young girl]376-the young girl . Having no self - pity , [she]1681-the girl never questioned the justice of the blow that had been dealt [her]1681-the girl . Afterwards , in the years to come , [she]1681-the girl might wonder why [she]1681-the girl should have been made to suffer so ? But not then . [One]1802-one 's first sorrow is a very precious thing . In those far - off days , [she]1681-the girl would gladly have sacrificed everything — even life itself — for [the young man who forgot to write , and whose face , with its rather foolish smile]441-the young man who forgot to write , and whose face , with its rather foolish smile , it is so difficult to recall exactly as it was . About this time , when [she]1681-the girl began to work at [the Central London School of Art]442-the central london school of art , [father]1669-father and [daughter]444-daughter became [great friends]445-great friends . On the days when [he]1669-father went to lecture at [the [London]3-london University]446-the london university , [she]1681-the girl would either walk with [him]1669-father , or go to fetch [him]1669-father on those afternoons when [he]1669-father was coming straight [home]1741-home to tea instead of making [his]1669-father way to [the Athenæum Club]11-the athenæum club . With [her]1681-the girl chin in the air , looking straight before [her]1681-the girl , [she]1681-the girl stepped along , in the half - dark , with a royal scorn for [the well - dressed loafers who find [their]448-the well - dressed loafers who find their pleasure in accosting ladies in the street pleasure in accosting [ladies]1767-ladies in [the street]450-the street]448-the well - dressed loafers who find their pleasure in accosting ladies in the street . [She]1681-the girl was twenty - one , and [a woman]451-a woman now ; it behoved [her]1681-the girl to be able to take care of [herself]1681-the girl . And after all , [they]452-they were perhaps more easily disposed of than some of [the men who took [her]1681-the girl in to dinner]453-the men who took her in to dinner , [men who had tired eyes and a dubious smile , and who were fond of starting doubtful topics with a side - long , tentative glance]454-men who had tired eyes and a dubious smile , and who were fond of starting doubtful topics with a side - long , tentative glance . [She]1681-the girl works now regularly with [[her]1681-the girl father]1846-her father , acting as [[his]1846-her father amanuensis]456-his amanuensis when [his]1846-her father eyes are tired , or verifying facts in [the library]457-the library . [Jimmie]130-jimmie , [the little brother]458-the little brother , has grown into [a boy with charming , insinuating manners]459-a boy with charming , insinuating manners , who is curiously un - British in [his]130-jimmie demonstrativeness . [[His]130-jimmie sister]460-his sister , [he]130-jimmie says , is the most charming of [girls]461-girls . [He]130-jimmie announces that [he]130-jimmie is always going to live with [her]460-his sister . Nothing shall separate [them]462-them . How well [she]460-his sister remembered the last time [she]460-his sister and [[her]460-his sister father]1846-her father had gone out together . [His]130-jimmie last book but one had but lately appeared , and was now being scratched and bespluttered assiduously by clerical pens , while it was received with rapture by the large class which like [their]462-them advanced thinking done for [them]462-them , and turned out in fat print with ample margins once in every third year . All the way up [the crowded staircase]466-the crowded staircase there is a great display of teeth , of tiaras , of stars and orders , of shining bald heads . [The wife of [the Foreign Secretary]468-the foreign secretary]467-the wife of the foreign secretary is delighted to see [the professor]308-the professor , though [no one in that eminently aristocratic gathering]470-no one in that eminently aristocratic gathering ‘ insists ’[467-the wife of the foreign secretary] on anything , and [most people]471-most people are content to exchange two fingers , two words , and two smiles , one at greeting and one at passing on . [His]130-jimmie Excellency [the German Ambassador]472-the german ambassador detains [the father]473-the father and [daughter]444-daughter , for [he]130-jimmie has just heard that [the Emperor]475-the emperor intends to bestow on [the English professor the Order of the Crown]476-the english professor the order of the crown , for [his]130-jimmie distinguished services to the progress of modern thought . [The two]477-the two move on , and are caught up in other small circles , where [they]477-the two hear agreeable commonplaces , in an atmosphere where everything is taken for granted , and in which smooth phrases and smooth faces abound , faces which have inherited , for hundreds of years , the art of expressing nothing in a polite way . It is all suave and artificial and decorous . No epigrams make [themselves]462-them conspicuous in the well - bred chatter , and [one great lady , exhibiting a superfluity of bare flesh]478-one great lady , exhibiting a superfluity of bare flesh , raises a tortoise - shell lorgnette when [some one — who can it be?—is]479-some one — who can it be?—is heard to laugh outright . [A famous guardsman]480-a famous guardsman has several charming things to say , and [the girl]1681-the girl finds [her]1681-the girl chatter received with flattering attention by [the handsome man with the Garter]482-the handsome man with the garter , who is at once [a Viceroy and the most suave of diplomats]483-a viceroy and the most suave of diplomats . Surely , when [one]1802-one looks back , [the girl]1681-the girl 's eyes are bright again that night ; [her]1681-the girl blond hair is full of electricity ; [she]1681-the girl has regained , though with a curious little composed manner , something of the roundness , the joyousness , of nineteen . Life is a compromise , and must not be taken too seriously . It is absurd to be much in earnest , and it bores [people]1883-people . So much [the girl]1681-the girl has learned . For the next two or three days , [the two]477-the two hardly left [the study]303-the study , except for a short walk after dinner , for [the professor]308-the professor 's book absorbed [him]308-the professor . Not feeling [himself]308-the professor , [he]308-the professor was anxious — terribly anxious — to get it done . After this [they]477-the two would go abroad , and get a long holiday . [He]308-the professor wanted to go to [Zermatt]12-zermatt . At [the Riffel Alp]491-the riffel alp [he]308-the professor would get the air and exercise [he]308-the professor craved . No , [he]308-the professor was not quite [himself]308-the professor ; [he]308-the professor felt over - strained , nervous , [he]308-the professor had a continual headache . It was , perhaps , [he]308-the professor said , a touch of bile . But one evening , just before dinner , the book was actually done . Bending over [the girl at the desk]492-the girl at the desk , [he]308-the professor kissed [her]1681-the girl crisp hair , and wrote at the bottom of the page , in [his]308-the professor own cramped hand , these words—‘The End . ’ And so it was , indeed . The next morning , when [the servant]1894-the servant went up to call [him]308-the professor , [the professor]308-the professor had been dead some hours . [The doctors]1896-the doctors spoke of a clot of blood in the brain , of over - work , and over - strain . And in [the tall , darkened house in [Harley Street]13-harley street]1897-the tall , darkened house in harley street , [the child who had played]1898-the child who had played , [the girl who had danced]1899-the girl who had danced , died too . AS sometimes happens with [busy people in [London]3-london]1900-busy people in london , [the Erles]150-the erles had hundreds of [acquaintances]1901-acquaintances and but [few intimate friends]1902-few intimate friends . A friendship is costly , in point of time , and [Mary]124-mary found , when one chapter of [her]124-mary life was done that spring morning , that there were [two people only that [she]124-mary must imperatively see]1903-two people only that she must imperatively see : [a man]1904-a man and [a woman]451-a woman — [Vincent Hemming]129-vincent and [Alison Ives]128-alison . How [their]1903-two people only that she must imperatively see features stood out among [the crowd of vague faces , which belonged to that other life]1906-the crowd of vague faces , which belonged to that other life ! [Alison Ives]128-alison especially , who always looked like [a Reynolds]151-a reynolds , with [her]128-alison handsome , clever face , [her]128-alison superb air , and [her]128-alison huge hats tied under the chin . With that grave sweetness which endears to [us]1907-us [the Siddons]152-the siddons in [the National Gallery]1908-the national gallery , [she]128-alison yet had the look of [a thinker , modernised by a slightly bored expression]1909-a thinker , modernised by a slightly bored expression , and a little distinguished way which at once made [other women in [her]128-alison vicinity]1910-other women in her vicinity look dowdy or vulgar . [Her]128-alison clothes always seemed to suit [her]128-alison , as its feathers do a bird . There are women who look like [an édition de luxe of a poor book]1911-an édition de luxe of a poor book ; [Alison Ives]128-alison suggested that of a classic . It had been [her]128-alison habit for a couple of years past to sit at the feet of [Professor Erle]123-professor erle ; [she]128-alison constantly announced , indeed , that [he]123-professor erle was [the only man [she]128-alison wanted to marry]1912-the only man she wanted to marry , only that [he]123-professor erle was firm , and would not permit it . Besides , it was no good trying to compete with [[her]128-alison mother]1709-her mother , [Lady Jane]131-lady jane , who was sixty - five — and irresistible . [Women of sixty - five]1914-women of sixty - five , [she]128-alison said , were nowadays [the only people who inspired a great passion]1915-the only people who inspired a great passion . [She]128-alison supposed [her]128-alison turn would come — a quarter of a century hence . But , all the same , [the daughter]310-the daughter was much admired in [the world]318-the world ; but [the world]318-the world , as understood by [[her]128-alison mother]1709-her mother , [Lady Jane]131-lady jane , by no means entirely satisfied [this eminently modern young woman]1920-this eminently modern young woman . It was whispered that [she]128-alison had serious views , though it was certain that [she]128-alison was pretty enough to please [a Prime Minister]1921-a prime minister , and clever enough to entertain [a guardsman]1922-a guardsman , if [she]128-alison found [herself]128-alison next to either at dinner . [Alison]128-alison did not mind which , [she]128-alison said ; in fact , after a long day in [the East - end]1923-the east - end , when [she]128-alison was tired , [she]128-alison rather preferred [the guardsman]1924-the guardsman , who would be content to talk of polo ponies , whereas , when [a young woman]1759-a young woman is put next to [a Premier]1926-a premier , it behoves [her]1759-a young woman to look , at any rate , very brilliant indeed . Though [she]128-alison never smoked , was ignorant of billiard cues and guns , and hated playing [the man]1927-the man , [Alison]128-alison had been heard to murmur something like an oath . It was a habit which [she]128-alison had picked up in [Paris]14-paris , when [she]128-alison was working in [[a sculptor]1928-a sculptor 's studio]1929-a sculptor 's studio ; and [she]128-alison always declared that [dame and sapristi]1930-dame and sapristi , being in a foreign tongue , were notoriously less efficacious , and by inference more pardonable , than swearing in the vernacular . For the rest , with the best heart in [the world]318-the world , [she]128-alison had a somewhat caustic tongue , could interpret [Chopin]153-chopin like [an artist]378-an artist , and always had [her]128-alison hair exquisitely dressed . What attracted [people]1883-people at once was [her]128-alison womanliness , [her]128-alison lack of snobbishness , [her]128-alison real desire to be in sympathy with [her]128-alison own sex . Like [all exceptional people]1934-all exceptional people , [she]128-alison had [her]128-alison moods , and sometimes for months together [she]128-alison was heard of only as forming one of a party in this or [that great country house]1935-that great country house , while at other times [she]128-alison would come to [town]1867-town and study fitfully , or devote [herself]128-alison to the task of helping [young girls]1937-young girls . Once , in the middle of the season , [she]128-alison took [a lodging in [a by - street]1939-a by - street in [the Mile End Road]1940-the mile end road]1938-a lodging in a by - street in the mile end road , but [she]128-alison only stayed seven weeks , and , when [she]128-alison appeared again , the expression on [her]128-alison face was sadder than before . ‘[308-the professor] Of course , [one]1802-one ought to know what it is like , ’ [she]128-alison said , when [Mary]124-mary asked [her]128-alison why [she]128-alison had left so soon . ‘[1802-one] It 's an experience — but a terrible one . It 's not only the drunkenness , the down - at - heel vice , the astounding absence of any thrift or forethought , and the incredible repetition of one solitary adjective ; but it seems to [me]0-i that , when [one or two of [us]495-we]494-one or two of us go and live down there , [we]495-we absolutely do no permanent good at all . [This spring]1941-this spring had found [her]128-alison ensconced in [[a workman]1942-a workman 's flat in [the Mayfair district]1944-the mayfair district]1943-a workman 's flat in the mayfair district , with [one small servant , whom [she]128-alison had befriended in [Whitechapel]15-whitechapel]1945-one small servant , whom she had befriended in whitechapel . ‘[497-her] But it 's as much for [myself]0-i as [her]497-her , ’ explained [Alison]128-alison , laughing . [She]128-alison hated to be thought philanthropic . ‘[498-all we women] [All we women]498-all we women are so incredibly dependent on [other people]340-other people . [We]495-we are all getting so pampered that [we]495-we ca n't exist without it . [People]1883-people do the most incredible things . [Mary]124-mary was bending over a desk , busy with [[her]124-mary father]1846-her father 's proofs , when [she]1948-the young woman who was shown into the study by elizabeth one morning a few days after the funeral at highgate came in . [The elder girl]1951-the elder girl 's beautiful brown eyes were suspiciously shiny ; it had evidently cost [her]1951-the elder girl an effort to come into [the study]303-the study which [she]1951-the elder girl knew so well . [The two girls]1953-the two girls wrung [each other]389-each other 's hands silently . But after the first kiss , in which [she]1951-the elder girl said everything that [she]1951-the elder girl dared not put in words , [Alison]128-alison , with [her]128-alison ready tact , began talking business at once . [The younger girl]1955-the younger girl announced [her]1955-the younger girl plans frankly . There was just enough money for [her]1955-the younger girl to live meagrely , quietly on for the next few years , while [she]1955-the younger girl tried [her]1955-the younger girl luck at art . [Mary]124-mary had always meant to paint some day , when [her]124-mary time should be at [her]124-mary own disposal . To paint was a long - cherished ambition , mused over on drowsy afternoons in [the reading - room of [the British Museum]19-the british museum]1956-the reading - room of the british museum , nursed during the days when [she]124-mary had remained bending over a desk in [[[her]124-mary father]1846-her father 's study]1958-her father 's study , patiently inscribing what [the professor]308-the professor dictated as [he]308-the professor walked up and down [the little room]1960-the little room . As for [Jimmie]130-jimmie , [he]130-jimmie was to remain at [Winchester]2-winchester , and , if [he]130-jimmie could succeed in winning a scholarship , was to go to [Oxford]20-oxford , as [the father]473-the father had wished . By living carefully this could be managed . ‘[508-no woman] [No woman]508-no woman ever made [a great artist]509-a great artist yet , ’ said [Alison]128-alison , after a pause , ‘[508-no woman] but , if [you]510-you do n't mind being third - rate , of course go in and try .
