And to complete the picture , [Jimmie]185-jimmie had apparently taken a seat for the afternoon at the table , and only raised [his]185-jimmie head from a novel to clamour for [his]185-jimmie tea . ‘[594-dear] Presently , [dear]594-dear , presently , ’ said [Mary]124-mary , hastily filling all the available bowls and vases with flowers . What could [she]124-mary do with [the boy]1684-the boy ? [she]124-mary wondered , as [she]124-mary ran into [[her]124-mary bedroom]379-her bedroom , put on the grey gown , and pinned some roses at [her]124-mary waist . ‘[0-i] [I]0-i say , [dearest]331-dearest , ’ said [Jimmie]185-jimmie , banging at the door , ‘[0-i] are n't [we]922-we ever going to have tea ? Or are [you]331-dearest waiting for [old Hemming]129-vincent ? ’ ‘[129-vincent] Oh , no , ’ said [Mary]124-mary faintly , still pondering what [she]124-mary could do with [[her]124-mary young brother]2446-her young brother . ‘[129-vincent] Tell [them]923-them to bring up the tea . ’ It was past six now ; [he]1684-the boy probably would come after dinner . That would be very nice — [they]922-we would have a beautiful long evening . [The rooms]2022-the rooms , too , did not look quite so dreadful at night . [She]124-mary had brought a small copper lamp , with a rose - coloured shade , in expectation of [Vincent]129-vincent 's arrival , so that those dreadful milky glass gas - globes would not have to be lighted . And then [she]124-mary had an idea . It was an extravagance which [she]124-mary would not have permitted [herself]124-mary , but then — — ‘[185-jimmie] [Jimmie]185-jimmie ! ’ [she]124-mary called out , as [she]124-mary stood at the looking - glass , [her]124-mary hands trembling as [she]124-mary tried to fasten the over - blown roses at [her]124-mary waist , while one by one the petals fell away and left a bare stalk . ‘[185-jimmie] Yes , [dearest]331-dearest . ’ ‘[185-jimmie] Would [you]185-jimmie like , for a treat , to go to [the theatre]1878-the theatre to - night ? There 's that piece still at [Drury Lane]63-drury lane with the real railway - engine in it , and [you]185-jimmie might go with [Smith major]926-smith major , [you]185-jimmie know . ’ [She]124-mary opened a drawer and took out [her]124-mary purse . There were ten shillings left out of [her]124-mary last cheque . Four shillings had been spent on flowers , but there was enough still to send [the two boys]2448-the two boys to [the theatre]1878-the theatre . ‘[926-smith major] Here 's six shillings , and mind [you]185-jimmie 're back at half - past eleven . ’[185-jimmie] And [Jimmie]185-jimmie was nothing loth . [He]185-jimmie insisted , however , on having fried eggs and bacon with [his]185-jimmie tea , and [Mary]124-mary resolved , when [the sitting - room]927-the sitting - room was finally saturated with the odour of fried fat , that [she]124-mary would say [she]124-mary was not at [home]1741-home if [Vincent]129-vincent called . But at last [the room]396-the room was aired , and [the house]316-the house quiet again . [Jimmie]185-jimmie had finally disappeared . The twilight of a summer evening settled on [the dingy room]931-the dingy room . [Mary]124-mary paced the floor , after crowding all [her]124-mary flowers on to the centre table , and opening the two windows wide to let in the sultry evening air . When [she]124-mary neared the window [she]124-mary listened intently for the sound of [cab - wheels]932-cab - wheels , or for that of on - coming footsteps . Yes , there were footsteps — footsteps coming to the door . There was an agitated ring of the bell , and [some one hurrying up the stairs]933-some one hurrying up the stairs . [Mary]124-mary got up from [her]124-mary chair , and stood with tightly - clasped hands , looking vaguely down at [the faded true - lovers]934-the faded true - lovers ' knots which meandered with foolish reiteration over the carpet . The door opened . It was [Jimmie]185-jimmie . ‘[933-some one hurrying up the stairs] Oh , [I]0-i say , dearest , [I]0-i quite forgot the six shillings [you]124-mary gave [me]0-i ! Where can [I]0-i have left them ? ’ And then a hunt began for the missing money . Presently it was found , and [Jimmie]185-jimmie had gone for the evening . It was very hot ; stuffy with the damp , vitiated air of a [London]3-london night verging on [August]212-august . [Few people]2450-few people passed . [Bulstrode Street]22-bulstrode street is [a quiet thoroughfare]2451-a quiet thoroughfare . Once , about eight o'clock , [cab - wheels]932-cab - wheels were audible , and then [Mary]124-mary shrank into the farthest corner of [the room]396-the room , clasping [her]124-mary little hands tight , and listening for the sound of the door - bell and that well - known step on the stair . But neither came . [The cab]2454-the cab drove on , having emptied its fare two doors off . It was nine o'clock now . ‘[0-i] [I]0-i am so lonely , so tired , ’ thought [the girl]1681-the girl . ‘[0-i] [I]0-i wish [he]935-he would come . [I]0-i want to talk to [some one who cares for [me]0-i , to get [my]0-i little share of happiness]936-some one who cares for me , to get my little share of happiness . [I]0-i wonder if [any man alive]937-any man alive really knows how dreadful it is to be [a woman]451-a woman , and to have to sit down , and fold [your]939-your hands , and wait ? ’ Half - past nine now . Still [he]935-he might come . [He]935-he would have dined at [[his]935-he club]2456-his club , in all probability , and [he]935-he would come on , after exchanging gossip with [the men [he]935-he would meet]2457-the men he would meet . [Mary]124-mary lighted the copper lamp now , and placed the pink shade over it . How pretty the flowers looked ! Only the roses at [her]124-mary belt were faded . Going into [the next room]2345-the next room , [she]124-mary pinned in a fresh bunch . A quarter to ten ? [He]935-he would hardly come now ; [he]935-he always had a nice eye to the proprieties . But [[his]935-he cab]2459-his cab might have broken down ; [he]935-he might have been detained at [the club]883-the club . The march up and down [the room]396-the room continued . [Mary]124-mary never knew how much [she]124-mary walked that night . The long , empty hours seemed interminable . But at last , in the still , sultry air , [she]124-mary could hear [Big Ben]213-big ben strike eleven . Oh , eleven ! Then it was all over ; [she]124-mary might as well take off the pretty grey dress , unpin the bunch of roses . At half - past eleven [Jimmie]185-jimmie returned , full of the delights of the play . ‘[0-i] Oh , [I]0-i say , [dearest]331-dearest , are [you]331-dearest sitting up ? Has n't [he]129-vincent been ? ’[0-i] ‘ [I]124-mary have n't seen anything of [him]129-vincent , ’[124-mary] said [Mary]124-mary . ‘ [I]124-mary suppose [he]129-vincent was too tired to come to - night . ’[124-mary] And though [she]124-mary went to bed soon after , [she]124-mary lay with [her]124-mary eyes wide open , until the grey dawn began to creep in behind the dingy white blind . And yet what had [they]943-they in common ? [HEMMING]129-vincent was there now , sitting on the hard sofa opposite , very bronzed since [she]124-mary had last seen [him]129-vincent , but studiously correct in [his]129-vincent town clothes and [his]129-vincent frothy white tie . And [you]129-vincent went to [Ottawa]66-ottawa — and [Niagara]67-niagara — ’ added [Mary]124-mary vaguely , as [people]1883-people always talk of places and countries [they]1883-people have never seen . ‘[129-vincent] And what is [Niagara]67-niagara like ? ’ ‘[129-vincent] [Niagara]67-niagara , ’ said [Hemming]129-vincent , with a certain solemnity , ‘[129-vincent] [Niagara]67-niagara is something like [London]3-london . The great falls , [you]952-you know , are not beautiful ; neither is [London]3-london . But they are , like [London]3-london , a unique , a terrifying spectacle . The roar , the immensity , the sense of a great power for ever driving forward ; all these things are identical . Some day , [Niagara]67-niagara will have dried up , retreated , become a mere dribble among waterfalls . Some day , [London]3-london will be a handful of ruins . ’ ‘[124-mary] What an unpleasant idea ! said [Mary]124-mary , laughing ; ‘ what dreadful things [you]129-vincent always think of ! ’[124-mary] And then , with a childish , frank outburst , [she]124-mary crossed to the sofa , knelt down on the floor , and , putting [her]124-mary two hands on [his]129-vincent shoulders , [she]124-mary shook [him]129-vincent gently . ‘ Why did n't [you]129-vincent come yesterday , ’[124-mary] [she]124-mary whispered . ‘ [You]129-vincent old silly , [you]129-vincent stopped and talked to [somebody at [the club]883-the club]2466-somebody at the club , [I]124-mary suppose ? ’[124-mary] But [Vincent]129-vincent did not hear . [Men]1679-men were like that , [she]124-mary thought . The horror of waiting , waiting , and waiting did not occur to [them]1679-men . [Her]124-mary cheeks had got hot ; there was colour enough in them now , and [her]124-mary hands shook as [she]124-mary poured out the tea which [the maid - of - all - work]2219-the maid - of - all - work had brought in . But [she]124-mary must not look as if [she]124-mary cared . [A woman]451-a woman — especially in [[her]451-a woman own house]969-her own house — should always smile . It was on that acquiescent feminine smile that the whole fabric of civilisation rested . And for the next half - hour , as [Vincent Hemming]129-vincent discoursed of the unusual opportunities [he]129-vincent had enjoyed in [Calcutta]72-calcutta , in [Sydney]73-sydney , and in [Ottawa]66-ottawa of studying the different systems of government which obtained in [various parts of [the British Empire]971-the british empire]970-various parts of the british empire , [Mary]124-mary was [a model hostess]972-a model hostess . And soon , too , [he]129-vincent was gone . Afterwards , [she]124-mary remembered , [he]129-vincent had spoken of seeing [her]124-mary again very soon , as [he]129-vincent kissed [her]124-mary cheek at the door — of taking [her]124-mary and [Jimmie]185-jimmie to [the theatre]1878-the theatre . And then [his]129-vincent close - cropped greyish hair , the back of [his]129-vincent shining collar , and [his]129-vincent well - cut frock coat , were seen descending the dingy staircase . And that was all . The meeting for which [she]124-mary had longed with all the ardour of a frank , loyal , and direct nature , had come and was over . [She]124-mary went into [the little dreary bedroom]974-the little dreary bedroom and threw [herself]124-mary on the narrow bed . No tears came . [She]124-mary lay blankly staring at the blue and green kingfisher , with the text in large German letters , ‘ Come unto [Me]124-mary all [ye]2482-ye that are heavy laden , and [I]124-mary will give [you]2482-ye rest . ’[124-mary] [She]124-mary wondered , vaguely , what connection there was between [a kingfisher]975-a kingfisher and that exquisitely touching phrase . And then [she]124-mary remembered how [[her]124-mary Aunt]976-her aunt [Julia]165-aunt julia , from the seclusion of [[her]165-aunt julia gabled Bournemouth villa]977-her gabled bournemouth villa , had once written [her]124-mary a long letter foreshadowing , with the perverse joy of the righteous , the day when [[her]165-aunt julia niece]978-her niece [Mary]124-mary would infallibly need the consolations of religion . [Her]124-mary Aunt [Julia]165-aunt julia had spoken of [her]124-mary as ‘ hardened . ’[165-aunt julia] Well , that exactly described [her]124-mary state of mind . [Mary]124-mary felt not only hardened , but petrified . What did it all mean ? [He]979-he was [hers]124-mary , was [he]979-he not , [the man who had just left [her]124-mary]980-the man who had just left her ? All [her]124-mary thoughts turned naturally to [him]979-he ; [she]124-mary was incapable now of comprehending a life which [they]981-they were not to share together . [She]124-mary was perfectly aware of [his]979-he little poses , [his]979-he not altogether amiable peculiarities , but [she]124-mary had got to the stage when they made no difference . A French wit has it that ‘ C'est le ridicule qui tue , ’[124-mary] an aphorism which may be true of politics , fashions , or art , but which , alack ! does not apply to the vagaries of human passion . [Vincent Hemming]129-vincent , once outside the door , felt in [his]129-vincent breast - pocket for [his]129-vincent cigar case , carefully chose a promising cigar , and thrust it firmly between [his]129-vincent teeth while [he]129-vincent stopped in a door - way to strike a match . [His]129-vincent sensations that afternoon were mixed . It had been , [he]129-vincent reminded [himself]129-vincent , delightful to see [little Mary]124-mary again . If only [he]129-vincent had not been so imprudent as to speak before [he]129-vincent went away . And yet what could [he]129-vincent do ? Curiously enough , [the girl]1681-the girl appealed to the sensuous side of [his]129-vincent nature . [Her]1681-the girl slight , thin shoulders , [her]1681-the girl long , delicate throat , the rather pathetic curve of [her]1681-the girl jaw , belonged to the type of beauty [he]129-vincent preferred . The nervous energy , which was [her]1681-the girl special characteristic , touched , while it troubled [him]129-vincent . As on the day that [he]129-vincent asked [her]1681-the girl to wait for [him]129-vincent , [he]129-vincent always , whatever [she]1681-the girl announced [her]1681-the girl intention of doing , felt constrained to interfere . [He]129-vincent admired [her]1681-the girl pluck , [her]1681-the girl perseverance , [her]1681-the girl dogged determination to get on , [her]1681-the girl fine appreciation of all that was best in literature and art . ‘ [She]1681-the girl 's [a little girl in a thousand]2483-a little girl in a thousand , ’[129-vincent] [he]129-vincent said to [himself]129-vincent , ‘ and not at all likely to make unpleasantness if things become impossible . Not that [one]1802-one would dream of doing anything but what was best for [her]1681-the girl ; but [she]1681-the girl 's young — [she]1681-the girl may see some one [she]1681-the girl likes better . By [Jove]215-jove ! [she]1681-the girl ought to make a really good match . ’[129-vincent] And in [his]129-vincent modesty [Mr. Hemming]129-vincent allowed [himself]129-vincent to caress this idea . [He]129-vincent pictured [her]1681-the girl , in many diamonds , at the head of a long dinner - table — a table scintillating with silver and crimson with roses , with [a vague , undefined husband at the other end]983-a vague , undefined husband at the other end . And [he]984-he , [Vincent]129-vincent , sat by [her]1681-the girl side , and [she]1681-the girl — [[his]129-vincent little Mary]985-his little mary — looked at [him]129-vincent , as [he]129-vincent talked , with [her]1681-the girl emotional eyes , and murmured pretty , sympathetic phrases with [her]1681-the girl deliciously curved lips . ‘ Who knows ? ’[129-vincent] [he]129-vincent muttered , throwing away the end of [his]129-vincent cigar , ‘ odder things have happened . ’[129-vincent] And then [he]129-vincent went over [his]129-vincent year of travel as [he]129-vincent strolled down [Regent Street]1-regent street on [his]129-vincent way to call at [the Métropole]74-the métropole . Everything , from the very beginning , had gone off smoothly . [He]129-vincent had enjoyed it from first to last . [His]129-vincent letters of introduction — [he]129-vincent had had excellent letters , [he]129-vincent reminded [himself]129-vincent — had brought [him]129-vincent in touch with [all the important men in [India]31-india and [the colonies]987-the colonies]986-all the important men in india and the colonies . [He]129-vincent had ample material for a book . The thing , it was true , had been somewhat overdone , but then [he]129-vincent was sure of [his]129-vincent style ; the book would not be written after the manner of the globe - trotting M.P. And yet , by the time the volumes were out , [he]129-vincent , too , would be among [[England]5-england 's legislators]988-england 's legislators . ( It was typical of [Hemming]129-vincent that [he]129-vincent always thought of [the hedge - row member of parliament]989-the hedge - row member of parliament as [a ‘ legislator]2485-a ‘ legislator . ’[2485-a ‘ legislator] ) [He]129-vincent had quite made up [his]129-vincent mind about that . Marriage might well be postponed a year or two , but for [a man]1904-a man to have any real influence on politics , [he]1904-a man must be in [the House]316-the house . As luck would have it , [the member for [Northborough]75-northborough]992-the member for northborough was known to be seriously ill , a lingering illness which must terminate fatally , and [the party]993-the party were already making arrangments for contesting the seat . [He]129-vincent had reason to know that [his]129-vincent candidature would be highly appreciated by [the Conservatives]216-the conservatives . All that was wanted were funds . And it was then that [his]129-vincent mind ran back to [his]129-vincent meeting with [[his]129-vincent new friends]994-his new friends . [He]129-vincent had found [them]994-his new friends first , [Mr.]995-mr. , [Mrs.]996-mrs. , and [Miss Violet Higgins]217-miss higgins , of [Northborough]75-northborough , [Lancashire]76-lancashire , engaged in a protracted quarrel with [the black porter]997-the black porter in [a train]998-a train bound [New York]77-new york - wards from [Niagara]67-niagara . [The Higgins family]999-the higgins family had wished to have the windows of [the long compartment]1000-the long compartment opened , but [the black porter , having no per- sonal objection to tropical heat]1001-the black porter , having no per- sonal objection to tropical heat , had insisted on shutting [every aperture]1002-every aperture . Finally , [Vincent]129-vincent had effected a compromise , and [the perspiring mayor]1003-the perspiring mayor and [mayoress of [Northborough]75-northborough]1004-mayoress of northborough had been , [he]129-vincent thought , somewhat unduly thankful . [The daughter]310-the daughter , [a young lady with beady eyes , a high colour and a complete absence of chin]1006-a young lady with beady eyes , a high colour and a complete absence of chin , had watched [him]129-vincent all the rest of the journey with extreme interest . [He]129-vincent had not liked [her]310-the daughter appearance or [her]310-the daughter manners ; [her]310-the daughter clothes were trimmed all over with gold braid , and [she]310-the daughter looked unnecessarily conscious on being addressed ; but this first aversion had worn off during the seven days on [the steamer]1007-the steamer , for [they]1008-they met again on [the wharf at [New York]77-new york]1009-the wharf at new york , in the rush and bustle of embarkation . [The father]473-the father , [a manufacturer of the staunchest Tory principles]1011-a manufacturer of the staunchest tory principles , took a curious fancy to [the young man]1776-the young man . Yes , [old Higgins]218-elijah higgins was inclined to be friendly . The next day [Mary]124-mary received a note from [Vincent]129-vincent , to the effect that [he]129-vincent was running up north on parliamentary business , but that [he]129-vincent hoped to see [her]124-mary very soon . The postscript was typical of [the man]1927-the man : ‘[0-i] [I]0-i rejoice to think that [you]1018-you are continuing [your]1018-you literary and artistic studies with [your]1018-you usual courage and energy . Only [I]0-i implore [you]1018-you to consider [your]1018-you health , mental and physical . [You]1018-you tell [me]0-i [you]1018-you are writing stories now — love stories , [I]0-i presume . Remember that work which entails a drain on both the imagination and the feelings is more exhausting than [you]1018-you perhaps imagine . ’ A month later , [Vincent]129-vincent was still at [Northborough]75-northborough , and [Mary]124-mary , whose drawing for [the Academy]638-the academy had again been refused , was working , all through the dog - days , at [her]124-mary new profession of [journalist]2504-journalist . IT was a bright October morning , and the light of mid - day fell searchingly on the pictures in their garish new frames . [Scotch mountain streams]2505-scotch mountain streams , [eastern bazaars]2506-eastern bazaars , [young ladies reading love - letters]2507-young ladies reading love - letters , [fishermen mending nets]2508-fishermen mending nets , ran promiscuously up the walls to the very cornice , or modestly hung on a level with the boots of [the spectator]2342-the spectator . Everywhere was the obvious , the threadbare , the banal ; everywhere there was a frank appeal to the Philistinism of [the picture - buying public]2510-the picture - buying public . It was press day at [the galleries of [the Society of United Artists]2512-the society of united artists]2511-the galleries of the society of united artists — [the Benighted Artists]2513-the benighted artists , as [they]2513-the benighted artists were called at [a certain club consecrated to the fine arts]2514-a certain club consecrated to the fine arts — so that , for once , there was a sprinkling of [people moving about the polished parquet floor]2515-people moving about the polished parquet floor . Indeed , in [a distant room]2516-a distant room there was even [a small crowd]2517-a small crowd ; but that , it appeared , was due to the fact that a buffet , spread with a York ham , a magnificent display of bath buns , and several decanters of fiery - looking sherry , presided over by [a young lady with arch manners and pendant ear - rings]2518-a young lady with arch manners and pendant ear - rings , had been provided to seduce [the austere journalist]2519-the austere journalist . Sounds of hilarity , as well as whiffs of tobacco smoke , frequently penetrated to [the large room where [Mary Erle]124-mary was taking notes]2520-the large room where mary erle was taking notes . [Shaggy - looking men]2521-shaggy - looking men , with wide - awake hats and Inverness capes of dubious freshness , strolled in twos out of [the luncheon room]2522-the luncheon room , lit a cigar , took a seat on the red velvet divan in the middle of [the room]396-the room , making incongruous figures enough as [they]2521-shaggy - looking men rested under the fronds of a giant palm , and fell to talking [Fleet Street]54-fleet street , until [one or the other]2524-one or the other , producing a watch , hastily rose and shuffled [downstairs]286-downstairs . These curious proceedings on the part of a certain portion of the press aroused some astonishment in [Mary]124-mary . The scene was as new to [her]124-mary as the work ; for [she]124-mary had only taken [the art critic]2526-the art critic 's place on [the Comet]81-the comet during the temporary illness of [that functionary]2346-that functionary . So [she]124-mary walked slowly , conscientiously round [the room]396-the room , stopping at every picture that [she]124-mary could possibly mention in [her]124-mary article , and stopping , too , before pictures which [an editorial hint]2529-an editorial hint had advised [her]124-mary [she]124-mary would have to mention whether [she]124-mary liked them or no . And in [the empty galleries]2561-the empty galleries the rays of an autumn sunset touched the threadbare ‘[0-i] [Romes ’]88-romes ’ and ‘[0-i] [Wargraves ’]89-wargraves ’ and ‘[0-i] [Cornish Fisher]90-cornish fisher - scenes ’ with its delicate golden fingers . One by one [the pressmen]2562-the pressmen and [the lady journalists]2563-the lady journalists had slipped away . The odour of tobacco was evaporating . Even [the buffet]2564-the buffet was deserted , save for [one elderly gentleman]2565-one elderly gentleman , who , as [he]2565-one elderly gentleman stood talking to [the presiding nymph]2566-the presiding nymph as [she]2566-the presiding nymph washed up the glasses , leaned heavily with one elbow on the table and regarded the empty decanters with a fixed smile . ‘[0-i] IT 'S the deuce of a wet day , [dearest]331-dearest , ’[185-jimmie] murmured [Jimmie]185-jimmie , strolling into [the sitting - room where [Mary]124-mary was writing]1077-the sitting - room where mary was writing . ‘ Must [you]124-mary really go out ? ’[185-jimmie] ‘ Yes , [dear]594-dear . [He]185-jimmie had shot up into [a curiously pretty and precocious boy]2570-a curiously pretty and precocious boy . It was characteristic of [him]185-jimmie that [he]185-jimmie addressed [[his]185-jimmie sister]460-his sister with as much politeness as any of [his]185-jimmie numerous loves . [Everybody]569-everybody agreed that [Jimmie Erle]130-jimmie was [a delightful boy]2573-a delightful boy . Laudatory adjectives abounded when [his]185-jimmie name was mentioned . But [Mary]124-mary had gone into [[her]124-mary bedroom]379-her bedroom now , and was rapidly doing up [her]124-mary hair , and putting on a waterproof . As [she]124-mary left [the room]396-the room there was a brief vision of [[her]124-mary brother]1683-her brother helping [himself]1683-her brother to a third serve of marmalade . The morning paper was at [his]1683-her brother elbow , and there was even a surreptitious box of cigarettes on the chimney - piece . ‘[0-i] [I]0-i think , ’ said [Mary]124-mary to [herself]124-mary as [she]124-mary clattered down the staircase in [her]124-mary flapping waterproof , ‘[0-i] that [Jimmie]130-jimmie will always be comfortable and happy . [He]130-jimmie will never have to go out on a wet day . ’ In [the underground railway]2578-the underground railway [it]2579-it was at any rate dry , and [Mary]124-mary could rest [her]124-mary back , tired with bending over a desk since nine o'clock . For a long time [she]124-mary had felt wretchedly weak . The strain of writing was intense ; there were whole mornings which [she]124-mary spent staring at a sheet of white paper on [her]124-mary desk . The only ideas [she]124-mary had , came at night , when [she]124-mary ought to have been asleep , and after hours of insomnia [she]124-mary would get up and go to [her]124-mary desk with every nerve in [her]124-mary body quivering . [Mary]124-mary told [herself]124-mary severely as [the train]2405-the train rattled on [its]2405-the train way to [Kensington]84-kensington that [she]124-mary could not afford to break down now . [She]124-mary wanted so much to retain [her]124-mary position on the Fan ; if [she]124-mary gave it up for a month there would be [a dozen women]2581-a dozen women ready to snatch it from [her]124-mary . Then , too , [she]124-mary was getting on with [her]124-mary three - volume novel , which was to appear in Illustrations , and there was the [Perry Jackson]173-perry article for the same paper , over which [she]124-mary had taken a deal of trouble , and to finish which [she]124-mary was on [her]124-mary way to [the new Associate 's house]2582-the new associate 's house . And [she]124-mary smiled as [she]124-mary thought how amused [Vincent]226-vincent would be to hear that [she]124-mary had met [Perry Jackson]173-perry again , and to learn that [she]124-mary had been chosen to write an article on The Time of Roses , and [the beautiful house and studio in which [the artist]643-the artist was now installed]2583-the beautiful house and studio in which the artist was now installed . And with the clarity of mental vision which is one of the first signs of ripened powers , [Mary]124-mary contrasted [the two men]2585-the two men : [Perry]173-perry with [his]173-perry ridiculous manners , [his]173-perry good heart , [his]173-perry stubborn determination to get on , and [his]173-perry curiously keen knowledge of [the public]688-the public ; [Vincent]226-vincent with [his]226-vincent smooth , charming phrases , [his]226-vincent good looks , [his]226-vincent vacillating nature . It was pouring rain as [Mary]124-mary stepped out of [Kensington High Street Station]91-kensington high street station . A heavy , pinkish sky lowered overhead , and the trees of [Holland House]92-holland house took on a strange metallic hue in the changing stormy light . The end of [the road]2587-the road was swallowed up in mist and rain , and on [the streaming pavement]2588-the streaming pavement , which reflected everything like a mirror , [she]124-mary could see a vision of [her]124-mary own umbrella hurrying along through the storm . By the time [she]124-mary rang the bell of [[Mr. Perry Jackson]173-perry 's imposing house]2589-mr. perry jackson 's imposing house [her]124-mary feet were soaked through . The subject of [her]124-mary article was at work on a large canvas when [she]124-mary was shown in . In [the vast studio]2598-the vast studio , with [its]2598-the vast studio vista of polished boards , [its]2598-the vast studio golden ceiling , and [its]2598-the vast studio tapestry - hung walls , [the artist]643-the artist made [a somewhat insignificant figure]2600-a somewhat insignificant figure , as [he]643-the artist stood on a step - ladder and reached up to put in a piece of background . The gorgeous colouring of [the great silent room]2601-the great silent room accentuated the paleness of [his]643-the artist features . With [his]643-the artist profile outlined against an alcove of golden mosaics , [he]643-the artist looked more than ever like [a grown - up [London]3-london street - boy , who had found [his]643-the artist way , by mistake , into [some oriental palace fashioned by superhuman hands]2603-some oriental palace fashioned by superhuman hands]2602-a grown - up london street - boy , who had found his way , by mistake , into some oriental palace fashioned by superhuman hands . The wan , veiled light of a rainy day crept through the great north window , and on [a small outer studio of glass]2604-a small outer studio of glass — destined for out - of - door effects — the rain pattered monotonously . Palms and azaleas in giant pots repeated the enchanting note of green which was visible through the glass walls of [the outer studio]2605-the outer studio . The huge canvas at which [he]643-the artist was at work represented [a convent garden]2606-a convent garden in the grey crepuscule of a summer evening . The pale , pensive faces of [young nuns , faces of unnatural loveliness , with haunting eyes and flower - like mouths , shadowed by wide blue headdresses]2607-young nuns , faces of unnatural loveliness , with haunting eyes and flower - like mouths , shadowed by wide blue headdresses , were seen bending over beds of white lilies , while here and there a transparent hand was stretched to gather the passionless , immaculate flowers . This picture , destined for next year 's Academy , was to be called ‘[130-jimmie] The Hour of Lilies . ’ [Mary]124-mary was startled when [she]124-mary looked at it . Only a short time ago [she]124-mary had suggested the subject to [him]643-the artist . [He]643-the artist must have set to work at once , leaving everything else . The picture was already blocked in . ‘[130-jimmie] Oh , [I]0-i say , this is good of [you]1082-you , ’ cried [Perry]173-perry , blushing crimson . It was ridiculous , for [they]2608-they had to see [each other]389-each other so often about the article that [they]2608-they had become like [old friends]2610-old friends . If [I]173-perry was married — or going to get married . ’[173-perry] ‘ And are [you]173-perry ? ’[124-mary] asked [Mary]124-mary , in a politely interested tone ; but something in [his]173-perry look made [her]124-mary drop [her]124-mary eyes , and [she]124-mary turned away , asking two or three embarrassed questions about a distant canvas on the wall . There was an awkward pause . Outside , the rain poured with a sibilant sound on the roof of [the glass studio]1087-the glass studio , and the great trees drooped , soaked and soddened with wet . It had grown dark in [the big room]781-the big room . [Perry]173-perry had thrown down [his]173-perry palette , and was standing gazing at [her]124-mary with a nervous , agitated look . [Mary]124-mary began to walk round [the studio]2597-the studio , the drips from [her]124-mary umbrella making tiny pools of wet on the polished parquet floor and on the eastern rugs . ‘ [I]124-mary really ought to go , ’[124-mary] [she]124-mary said nervously , looking down ; ‘ [[your]173-perry room]2625-your room is much too gorgeous for [a damp journalist]2626-a damp journalist . ’[124-mary] [He]173-perry hurried forward imploringly , [his]173-perry sharp face whiter than ever with emotion , and for years after [she]124-mary could not forget the painful scene which followed . [She]124-mary remembered how [she]124-mary had been intensely conscious of [her]124-mary damp boots and of the little spots of water which [her]124-mary dripping waterproof made on the polished floor , while [Mr. Perry Jackson]173-perry , who , in moments of intense excitement , had an occasional difficulty with [his]173-perry aspirates , proffered [her]124-mary [his]173-perry name and fortune , and the undisturbed possession of [the Venetian drawing - room]1037-the venetian drawing - room , [the amber and gold dining - room]1091-the amber and gold dining - room , and a Japanese boudoir on [the first floor]1092-the first floor . In the pause that followed there was no sound but that of the pitiless rain hissing on the outer studio roof . [Mary]124-mary stood with [her]124-mary eyes fixed on the polished boards . How could [he]173-perry have misunderstood [her]124-mary so — what could [she]124-mary say to soften it ? Did n't [he]173-perry know ? Did n't [he]173-perry understand that it was impossible ? Well , [she]124-mary must say something . As evening fell , [he]173-perry was still working . THE first act was over , the curtain was down again . A buzzing sound was heard all over [the theatre]1878-the theatre . [Men]1679-men were standing up in the stalls , raking [the house]316-the house with [their]1679-men opera - glasses ; [the critics]1103-the critics were seen exchanging significant looks and portentous monosyllables ; while here and there was visible the profile of [a pretty woman]2149-a pretty woman craning [her]2149-a pretty woman neck to be seen speaking to [some distant celebrity]1105-some distant celebrity . [The house]316-the house , viewed from above , was one compact mass of [human beings]2097-human beings , the clear , pale dresses of [the women]1108-the women making gay patches among the rows of black coats , white shirt fronts , and slightly bald heads of [the men]2038-the men . It was the first night of a new comedy at [a modish theatre]1110-a modish theatre . In the private boxes the little canvas doors opened continually , revealing a glimpse of [the begilded corridor]1111-the begilded corridor darkened by the figure of [a man in evening dress]1112-a man in evening dress . And with this new care pressing upon [her]124-mary , never had [the Strand]94-the strand seemed so dreary , so cheaply vicious , as to - day under the hurrying clouds . ‘[124-mary] Spesh — shul!—Globe piper — [St. James 's Gizett]1182-st. james 's gizett — [Pall Mall]95-pall mall , ’ shouted [a newsboy]2719-a newsboy in [her]124-mary ear , at [Charing - cross]96-charing - cross ; and looking down [she]124-mary read , in blue or red letters , spattered and stained with [London]3-london mud , the posters of the evening newspapers:—‘The Great Divorce Case . Cross - examination of [the Plaintiff , Unabridged Report]2720-the plaintiff , unabridged report . [Ladies]1767-ladies ordered out of [Court]97-court . Sketches of [the Co - respondents]2722-the co - respondents . ’[124-mary] For the Blaythewaite scandal hung , like a pestilence , over [England]5-england . Like some foul miasma , it poisoned everything . It met the eye , in columns of close print , at the breakfast table ; it formed the one subject of conversation wherever [people]1883-people met . With hoarse laughs and brutal jests , it was discussed in [public - houses]1184-public - houses and at [street corners]1185-street corners ; with tepid , meaning smiles and shrugged shoulders in drawing - rooms and [clubs]1186-clubs . And meanwhile the great tide of humanity swept on . [A dray]1187-a dray had got across [the crowded street]1188-the crowded street , and a procession of [loaded omnibuses]1189-loaded omnibuses , whose drivers were bandying oaths and scathing cockney satire , drew up at [the curb]1190-the curb . [Outside Charing Cross station]1191-outside charing cross station [two girls in tawdry capes]1192-two girls in tawdry capes were quarrelling and gesticulating , while [a man in a round hat , who had just arrived by train , and who appeared to be the cause of the dispute]1193-a man in a round hat , who had just arrived by train , and who appeared to be the cause of the dispute , turned from [them]1192-two girls in tawdry capes both , hailed a hansom , and drove off with a relieved air . [A small gaping crowd]1194-a small gaping crowd at once gathered round [the wranglers on the pavement]1195-the wranglers on the pavement . ‘ Run 'em[1194-a small gaping crowd] both in , ’ said a raucous voice on the fringe of [the crowd]2723-the crowd ; and , indeed , [a policeman]2724-a policeman 's helmet was now seen bearing down towards [the group]391-the group . [Mary]124-mary hurried on . Further on there were [sordid little eating - houses]2726-sordid little eating - houses displaying a joint of raw meat , a cauliflower , and a plate of oysters ; and dark narrow passages — the entrance to [theatres]2727-theatres — ornamented with coloured posters of the latest three - act farce . Inexpressibly dreary were the pictures which invited one within : representations of [elderly ladies in black silk , falling backwards into hip - baths]2728-elderly ladies in black silk , falling backwards into hip - baths : monster heads of [comedians , with flaxen wigs and brick - red complexions]2729-comedians , with flaxen wigs and brick - red complexions , displaying all [their]2729-comedians , with flaxen wigs and brick - red complexions teeth in a frightful grin ; full - length posters of [girls with knowing smiles and abnormally developed limbs]2730-girls with knowing smiles and abnormally developed limbs ; while further on , outside [a music - hall]2731-a music - hall , was the picture of [a raffish - looking dwarf , who was described with engaging optimism as ‘[1194-a small gaping crowd] screamingly funny . ’]2732-a raffish - looking dwarf , who was described with engaging optimism as ‘ screamingly funny . ’ ‘[240-spesh] [Spesh]240-spesh — shul ! This was what [she]124-mary was to write — if [she]124-mary wanted to make any money , to keep [her]124-mary head above water . There was a vague odour of medicine , overpowered by that of patent disinfectants . [She]128-alison could not bear it . [She]128-alison was tired , [her]128-alison head ached , [her]128-alison throat felt dry ; [she]128-alison must have caught a chill . [She]1681-the girl died to - day . ’[693-the doctor] There was a burst of laughter from each side of the table . [The Attorney - General]2903-the attorney - general had just told [his]2903-the attorney - general newest story . [Dr. Dunlop Strange]178-dr. dunlop strange was carefully peeling a fine pear as [she]1319-her spoke . In the pause that followed [he]178-dr. dunlop strange continued to separate the fruit from its perfumed skin , bending a little , in [his]178-dr. dunlop strange short - sighted way , over [his]178-dr. dunlop strange Sèvres plate . All [his]178-dr. dunlop strange future life , [he]178-dr. dunlop strange knew , was involved in [her]1319-her next few words . ‘ [[My]178-dr. dunlop strange dear]542-my dear [Miss Ives]255-miss ives , ’[178-dr. dunlop strange] [he]178-dr. dunlop strange said , with something of [his]178-dr. dunlop strange consulting - room manner , ‘ pray , do n't judge hastily . [You]255-miss ives have probably only heard half [her]1319-her story . Do [you]255-miss ives , now , really know anything about [her]1319-her ? ’[178-dr. dunlop strange] ‘ Yes , ’[128-alison] said [Alison]128-alison , abruptly . And , as [she]128-alison looked [him]178-dr. dunlop strange straight in the eyes , [he]178-dr. dunlop strange knew that [she]128-alison was aware of the whole sordid story . ‘ [I]128-alison 'm[128-alison] not particularly sentimental , as [you]178-dr. dunlop strange know , ’ [she]128-alison added ; ‘[128-alison] but [I]0-i 've made up [my]0-i mind that [that poor creature]1320-that poor creature shall be decently buried in [the little country churchyard in [Sussex]100-sussex]1321-the little country churchyard in sussex , [in [the village]1323-the village where [she]1320-that poor creature used to live]1322-in the village where she used to live . [I]0-i should like [her]1320-that poor creature to rest now — for good . Shall [I]0-i make the necessary arrangements , or will [you]178-dr. dunlop strange , ’ [she]128-alison added with a shade of irony , ‘[178-dr. dunlop strange] prefer , perhaps , to do so — ? ’ [They]2945-they were standing up now , for [the ladies]518-the ladies , gathering up [their]518-the ladies fans and gloves , were about to leave [the room]396-the room . [He]178-dr. dunlop strange looked at [her]128-alison humbly , imploringly , but the beautiful candid eyes were quite hard . ‘[0-i] [I]0-i — [I]0-i — perhaps it would be better , on the whole , if [you]178-dr. dunlop strange allowed [me]0-i to see to it . ’ Nothing more was said . [He]178-dr. dunlop strange sat down again when [she]128-alison was gone , staring blankly at the fruit - strewn plates and half - drained glasses , at the tall flower - stands and flickering candles . [Her]128-alison crumpled napkin fell across [his]178-dr. dunlop strange knee , and , as it fell , [he]178-dr. dunlop strange saw , with a shudder , a vision of [a stiff , silent figure]2948-a stiff , silent figure in [the hospital mortuary]2949-the hospital mortuary . [He]178-dr. dunlop strange could hear the rustle of silk dresses , and the sound of feminine voices as [the ladies]518-the ladies trailed [upstairs]1832-upstairs . And [he]178-dr. dunlop strange knew as [he]178-dr. dunlop strange heard [them]518-the ladies go that it was all over . Yes , it was all over , for [she]128-alison , at any rate , was [not one of [those girls who have infinite complaisances for [a possible husband]2954-a possible husband]2953-those girls who have infinite complaisances for a possible husband]2952-not one of those girls who have infinite complaisances for a possible husband . [A man]1904-a man drew up [his]178-dr. dunlop strange chair , asked for a light , and began to talk of a bit of scandal that was then enjoying high favour at [the clubs]2956-the clubs . [Strange]178-dr. dunlop strange stared at [him]178-dr. dunlop strange with haggard eyes , got up , made some excuse , and left [the house]316-the house . TWO or three days after the dinner in [Portman Square]41-portman square , as [Mary]124-mary was trying to impart an air of reality to [her]124-mary ‘[178-dr. dunlop strange] society ’ article in The Fan — a task at which [she]124-mary was busy on three mornings of every month — a pencil note was brought from [Alison]128-alison , dated , to [her]124-mary surprise , from [Portman Square]41-portman square . ‘[1324-dear little girl] [Dear little girl]1324-dear little girl , ’ it said , ‘[1324-dear little girl] [I]0-i 'm down with an awful cold — bronchitis , [I]1324-dear little girl think . [The doctor]693-the doctor says [I]1324-dear little girl 'm[1324-dear little girl] not to get up . It 's such a nuisance [my]0-i being seedy , because to - day is [Evelina]154-evelina 's wedding - day . [She]154-evelina 's to be married at 2.30 . Will [you]1324-dear little girl , like [a dear]2167-a dear , go and see that [she]154-evelina 's dressed , and bring [her]154-evelina here to [me]0-i ? And [my]0-i presents — the tea - service , and the work - basket , and the new cot for [the baby]1838-the baby — see that [she]154-evelina has them , wo n't you?—Yours , [ALISON]128-alison . ’ ‘[1927-the man] Tell [the man]1927-the man , ’ said [Mary]124-mary to [the stolid maid - of - all - work]2959-the stolid maid - of - all - work , who was waiting , with pendant red hands and slightly open mouth , at the door , ‘[1927-the man] that [I]0-i shall be round in half an hour . ’ There were still another dozen lines to write . The thing must be neatly turned , made acidulous and sparkling . It took some fifteen minutes of writing and scratching out . Then mechanically [she]124-mary ran [her]124-mary eye once again over the lines , tied up the sheets of MSS . , and directed it to [the editor]2182-the editor before [she]124-mary left [the house]316-the house . [Mary]124-mary found [the bride]909-the bride all dressed and ready when [she]124-mary reached [the flat]913-the flat . Always [a silent girl]2964-a silent girl , who accepted things as [they]2965-they came , [Evelina]154-evelina seemed to - day paralysed with the excitement of [her]154-evelina position . In silence [they]2965-they drove in [a four - wheel cab]533-a four - wheel cab to [Portman Square]41-portman square . There were many chintz draperies , patterned with sprawling pink roses ; the pillows were trimmed with deep lace , and the ample silk eider - down quilt was of a piercing blue . [Little pot - bellied Loves]1339-little pot - bellied loves disported [themselves]1339-little pot - bellied loves on the round looking - glass , and a number of slim gold - and - white chairs were placed about [the room]396-the room . A bronchitis - kettle was steaming near the bed , and bright sunshine lay along the counterpane and in patches on the carpet . ‘ Here [she]128-alison is ! ’[124-mary] said [Mary]124-mary ; and [Evelina]154-evelina , with loudly - creaking boots , stepped , gawky and embarrassed in [her]154-evelina finery , to the bedside , [her]154-evelina red cheeks and wrists accentuated by the pallor of [her]154-evelina soiled white - silk frock . It was only quite at the last that [I]0-i knew for certain . ’ The winter dusk fell early in [the spacious bed - room]2988-the spacious bed - room . There was a terrible tension in the air . The very atmosphere seemed charged with feminine emotion , as [the two girls , exaggerating , as over - refined women]2989-the two girls , exaggerating , as over - refined women will , the importance of ethical standards of conduct in the great teeming universe , talked on and on in the gathering gloom . It was dark when [Lady Jane]131-lady jane returned , bringing with [her]0-i large , pink cheeks , [her]0-i parted hair , [her]0-i rustling silk clothes , an air at once motherly and mundane into [the sick room]2990-the sick room . ‘[0-i] [I]0-i shall insist , [[my]0-i darling]598-my darling , on [your]598-my darling seeing [some one else]1240-some one else , ’ [she]0-i announced in [her]0-i rather loud but cheery voice . ‘[0-i] [I]0-i can quite understand [your]598-my darling not wishing to see [[our]1384-our dear]1275-our dear [Dunlop]178-dr. dunlop strange , for [[we]1384-our women]1386-we women , ’ [she]0-i added with a sigh , ‘[178-dr. dunlop strange] all have [our]1384-our little coquetries . [Mary]124-mary went down to [the dining - room]1678-the dining - room when the bell rang , leaving [[Alison]128-alison 's old nurse]2995-alison 's old nurse at the bedside side . And [they]1389-they say [the poor young man]1390-the poor young man had led a perfectly shocking life . ’ ‘[1389-they] [Dear Lady Jane]229-lady jane , ’ urged [Mary]124-mary , ‘[1389-they] pray do n't insist on it to [her]0-i . It would be worse than useless — it really would do harm . ’ [She]124-mary had made up [her]124-mary mind to say nothing about ‘[1389-they] Number Twenty - seven , ’ and [her]124-mary sordid little tragedy . [Lady Jane]229-lady jane was kind and charming , but [she]229-lady jane had retained the prejudices of [ladies who were young in the fifties]2997-ladies who were young in the fifties . Certainly [she]229-lady jane would never comprehend [[her]229-lady jane daughter]1134-her daughter 's extremely modern sympathy for [this woman who had drawn [her]1134-her daughter last breath in [a hospital ward]3001-a hospital ward]3000-this woman who had drawn her last breath in a hospital ward . It was settled that [Mary]124-mary should remain all night at the bedside . There were a dozen things to think of : food , stimulants , medicines , blisters . [She]229-lady jane ran over carefully in [her]229-lady jane mind all that [she]229-lady jane would have to do during the night . Towards ten o'clock , [the sick girl]1355-the sick girl sat up , saying [she]1355-the sick girl could breathe easier in that position . ‘[1389-they] Oh , how [I]0-i hate being ill , ’ [she]0-i muttered , clenching [her]0-i fingers as they lay on the counter - pane . ‘[124-mary] [Mary]124-mary , ’ [she]0-i continued , while the irritable anxious look deepened on [her]0-i face for [she]0-i had to stop—‘I feel , ’[0-i] [she]0-i gasped at last , ‘ as if [I]0-i were choking . ’[0-i] ‘ [Dear]594-dear , ’[901-the other girl] said [the other girl]901-the other girl , ‘ why do n't [you]594-dear lie down ? ’[901-the other girl] ‘ [I]0-i can't — [I]0-i ca n't breathe if [I]0-i do . There is the personal degradation — [one]1802-one looks odious , [one]1802-one is odious . ’[0-i] ‘ [Dear]594-dear , [you]594-dear will be all right again in a day or two , ’[124-mary] urged [Mary]124-mary . ‘ Oh ! [I]124-mary do n't mean that , ’[124-mary] [she]124-mary muttered , falling back . ‘ It does n't matter ; nothing matters , nothing matters , ’[124-mary] [she]124-mary went on till [she]124-mary fell into an uneasy dose . [She]124-mary was lying tossing from one side to the other with [her]124-mary head lower than [her]124-mary shoulders , when [Dr. Danby]238-dr. danby came again at eleven . ‘ How long has [the patient]2809-the patient been in that position ? ’[2710-the great man] whispered [the great man]2710-the great man . Something in the tone of [his]2710-the great man voice made [her]124-mary heart stand still . ‘ [She]2809-the patient 's been lying like that all the time — when [she]2809-the patient is n't sitting up coughing , ’[1681-the girl] faltered [the girl]1681-the girl . ‘ Ah ! [We]3009-we must keep up [the patient]2809-the patient 's strength in every way . It 's very serious now , [Miss Erle]126-miss erle . ’[1681-the girl] [Mary]124-mary heard the words , but they sounded a long way off . ‘ [I]229-lady jane WILL not , while [I]229-lady jane have health and strength , ’[229-lady jane] said [Lady Jane]229-lady jane severely at the breakfast table , when the question of [a trained nurse]1394-a trained nurse was mooted , ‘ consent to have [[my]229-lady jane child]1170-my child nursed by [a hireling]3012-a hireling . It is a [mother]1804-mother 's duty , ’[229-lady jane] [she]229-lady jane continued , with lofty decision , regarding [Mary]124-mary and [her]124-mary red , tired eyelids somewhat reproachfully . And [Lady Jane]229-lady jane , to be sure , was convinced that [she]229-lady jane [herself]229-lady jane had tended [the sick girl]1355-the sick girl through the night . [Mary]124-mary remembered , with something like a smile , that once or twice during that long vigil , [[her]124-mary hostess]2151-her hostess , arrayed in a somewhat short night - dress , scantily covered by a pink dressing - gown , had stepped ponderously into [the room]396-the room , upset one or two medicine bottles , and poured some beef - tea into a glass which contained lemonade . [Lady Jane]229-lady jane had the best intentions , but nature had not cut [her]229-lady jane out for [a sick nurse]1398-a sick nurse . [She]229-lady jane was short - sighted and easily perturbed , and [her]229-lady jane natural emotions overcame [her]229-lady jane so much that once [she]229-lady jane retreated in tears , carrying away in [her]229-lady jane distraction the bottle of medicine which was to be administered every hour . ‘ No , ’[1816-the mother] reiterated [the mother]1816-the mother ; ‘ not while [I]1816-the mother have health and strength . [I]1816-the mother shall go to [her]1398-a sick nurse [myself]1816-the mother immediately . ’[1816-the mother] The hours passed mournfully enough . There was no improvement during the day . [Alison]128-alison sat up in bed , propped up with pillows , while [her]128-alison strength lasted . [Her]128-alison face , which had gradually turned livid , was covered with a clammy perspiration . Every now and again [she]128-alison pushed back the damp strands of hair from [her]128-alison forehead . The fits of choking became more frequent ; [she]128-alison had no longer the strength to battle with [them]1400-them . ‘ [Mary]124-mary , ’[128-alison] [she]128-alison whispered once during the morning , ‘ [my]128-alison feet look so odd . They are swelling — [I]128-alison wonder why ? ’[128-alison] [She]128-alison pushed one foot from under the bed - clothes ; it was quite disfigured already . ‘ Funny it looks , ’[128-alison] [she]128-alison muttered . ‘ What 's [his]1398-a sick nurse name ? [the French sculptor]3014-the french sculptor — [you]124-mary know — modelled [my]128-alison foot once . It would be horrid’—she stared vacantly at the little swollen foot , while [Mary]124-mary bent down and rearranged the bed - clothes—‘to have great fat feet like that . [Mary]124-mary , do [you]124-mary think [they]3015-they will get slim again when [I]128-alison am well ? ’[128-alison] ‘ [[My]1896-the doctors darling]598-my darling , of course , of course . ’[1896-the doctors] Again [the sick woman]2980-the sick woman fell into an uneasy doze . [The doctors]1896-the doctors ' visit brought small comfort . [Both]3017-both bent with anxious faces over the bed . Little could be done but to administer strong restoratives . [The two physicians]3018-the two physicians feared some cerebral complication . ‘[1896-the doctors] Had [the patient]2809-the patient , ’ [they]3018-the two physicians asked [Lady Jane]229-lady jane , ‘[128-alison] recently had any mental shock ? ’ ‘[1896-the doctors] Certainly not , certainly not . [[My]0-i poor darling]1404-my poor darling , ’ replied [the mother]1816-the mother , ‘[0-i] was the picture of health and happiness . [The two doctors]3021-the two doctors glanced at [each other]389-each other and said nothing . [Mary]124-mary detained [the elder man]3023-the elder man [downstairs]286-downstairs . ‘[0-i] Tell [me]0-i the truth , ’ [she]0-i said . ‘[0-i] [[My]0-i dear [young lady]1406-young lady]2733-my dear young lady , [I]0-i fear there is nothing — absolutely nothing — that can be done . [The patient]2809-the patient is sinking rapidly . In all probability [she]2809-the patient will not live through another day . It would be well if [you]1408-you could break it to [[her]2809-the patient poor mother]1130-her poor mother . ’ [Mary]124-mary stood still for a minute , leaning against the passage wall , as [the two doctors]3021-the two doctors closed the door softly . [She]124-mary heard [the two carriages]3026-the two carriages roll away — rolling away to [other sick rooms]3027-other sick rooms , to pronounce , perhaps , another sentence of death before [they]3026-the two carriages reached [home]1741-home . It was nothing to [them]3026-the two carriages , [she]124-mary remembered ; nothing , nothing , nothing . [People]1883-people died every day . Every day [people]1883-people were born . [Some]3031-some had to go , [these men of science]3032-these men of science would say , to make way for [others]2714-others . ‘[1408-you] There seems to be no change — for the better , ’ whispered [Lady Jane]229-lady jane an hour later , as [they]1411-we both stood at the bedside . ‘[1408-you] [She]2809-the patient is still asleep , and muttering , [[my]0-i poor darling]1404-my poor darling . With a thing so poignant , so human , so pitiful as death , it seemed impossible that [this charming lady]3039-this charming lady could ever be associated . [The mother]1816-the mother broke down completely , and had to be led away . Towards four o'clock [someone]1680-someone knocked at the door , bringing up letters for [Mary]124-mary . [They]3042-they had been sent round from [the lodgings in [Bulstrode Street]22-bulstrode street]3043-the lodgings in bulstrode street . There were several letters : one from [Jimmie]130-jimmie , one from [[her]124-mary bootmaker]3044-her bootmaker , and one [she]124-mary saw , with a curious tight feeling at [her]124-mary heart , was from [Vincent]129-vincent , and bore a Northborough post - mark . Going to the window , [she]124-mary bent forward in the failing light and broke the seal . [Northborough]75-northborough , Dec. 3rd . ‘MY[0-i] DEAR [MARY,—You]265-mary,—you are perhaps aware that to - morrow is fixed for [my]0-i marriage , and it is no exaggeration to say that [I]0-i shall not feel happy when [I]0-i stand at the altar in the morning unless [I]0-i have a word of blessing from [you]265-mary,—you , [[my]0-i oldest and most valued friend]1412-my oldest and most valued friend , on this most auspicious occasion . There was a small cheque from a newspaper ; a little note — very affectionate — from [Jimmie]130-jimmie , requesting the loan of three pounds ; and lastly , [a bootmaker]1416-a bootmaker 's bill . [Jimmie]130-jimmie wanted three pounds , to be forwarded immediately . It was annoying — [he]130-jimmie was always asking for money , in little notes full of the most endearing epithets . Well , there was the present cheque . It was for three guineas — the price of one of [her]1415-your devoted friend articles — so [she]1415-your devoted friend could send [him]130-jimmie a post - office order . As for [the bootmaker]1417-the bootmaker , [he]130-jimmie would have to wait . There was something absurd , incongruous about [that bootmaker]1418-that bootmaker 's bill . And yet after all , [one]1802-one had to pay [one]1802-one 's boot bill , even if [[one]1802-one 's lover]1422-one 's lover was going to be married in the morning . [She]1415-your devoted friend felt a curious tightening in [her]1415-your devoted friend chest , a horrible feeling in [her]1415-your devoted friend head , as if the brain were pressing against the skull . Something had to be done — to be done at once , [she]1415-your devoted friend kept saying to [herself]1415-your devoted friend . Yes , [Vincent]129-vincent must be congratulated . [Her]1415-your devoted friend pride was up in arms . It would be undignified to look as if [she]1415-your devoted friend were considering the matter . [Women]1964-women , [she]1415-your devoted friend bethought [her]1415-your devoted friend with a grim smile , should accept [their]1964-women fate with a graceful acquiescence . And at once [Mary]124-mary made up [her]124-mary mind that [she]124-mary would not write , although there was just time to catch the country post . It would be better to telegraph . [She]124-mary would go [herself]124-mary to [the nearest office]1424-the nearest office . Gathering up [her]124-mary letters , [she]124-mary crept to the bedside . [Alison]128-alison was asleep . Bending down [she]124-mary kissed the white wrist that lay on the counterpane , and then , telling [the maid]1425-the maid not to move from [the sick - room]1426-the sick - room , [she]124-mary threw on [her]124-mary hat and cloak and left [the house]316-the house in the gathering dusk . It was not far to [the nearest post - office]1428-the nearest post - office , in [Baker Street]109-baker street , and once inside [she]124-mary carefully wrote out a post - office order for [Jimmie]130-jimmie . Then [she]124-mary took a telegraph form and wrote two or three different phrases with the blunt pencil tied to a short piece of string . Finally , when [she]124-mary had scratched out two or three messages , [she]124-mary handed the paper across to [the clerk]1429-the clerk . ‘ [I]124-mary wish [you]1681-the girl all possible happiness.—Mary , ’[124-mary] read out [the young man]1776-the young man in [his]1776-the young man everyday , unemotional voice , and then [the girl]1681-the girl found [herself]1681-the girl outside , walking rapidly down [Baker Street]109-baker street towards [the Regent 's Park]2401-the regent 's park . ‘ [I]1681-the girl must walk ; [I]1681-the girl must breathe the open air , ’[1681-the girl] [she]1681-the girl said to [herself]1681-the girl , ‘ or [I]1681-the girl shall never be able to sit up again all to - night . ’[1681-the girl] The gates of [the Regent 's Park]2401-the regent 's park were shut , but [she]1681-the girl walked on , round the outer circle , seeing nothing , for [her]1681-the girl brain was busy with two overpowering thoughts , the awful struggle with death , the protest against annihilation which was slowly being fought out in [that bedroom in [Portman Square]41-portman square]1434-that bedroom in portman square , and the fact that henceforward [she]1681-the girl was to walk alone , to fight the battle of life unaided — [a moral starveling , whose natural instincts were to be pinched , repressed , and neatly trimmed in conformity with the rules of the higher civilisation]1435-a moral starveling , whose natural instincts were to be pinched , repressed , and neatly trimmed in conformity with the rules of the higher civilisation . And , in sooth , it was in accordance with the inexorable laws of the higher civilisation that so priceless a boon as a loyal love should weigh as nothing when balanced with a thing which had a nicely ascertained value in the money market . Pausing on [the North Gate bridge]1436-the north gate bridge , [she]1681-the girl looked down into [the dark canal water]1437-the dark canal water , on to which the last shivering autumnal leaves were slowly fluttering down . [She]1681-the girl thought of [the girl]1681-the girl — of Number Twenty - seven — who had tried to drown [herself]1681-the girl in [those greenish , slimy waters]1439-those greenish , slimy waters . After all , it was but the Open Door of [the Greek philosophers which]110-the greek philosophers which [[she]1681-the girl had tried to slip through with uncertain , unsuccessful feet]1440-she had tried to slip through with uncertain , unsuccessful feet .... The curve of [the road outside]1441-the road outside was all a silvery grey . [Road]1442-road , sky , and [pavement]1443-pavement were clothed in the same neutral tint , but the street lamps made an orange sickle of fire , heightened on the other side by the indigo blueness of [the park]2356-the park , etched with intricate lines of bare stems and branches . The scarlet of [a mail - cart]1445-a mail - cart flashed past , and afterwards , in the solitude of [the grey road]1446-the grey road , [a shabby , belated mourning carriage]1447-a shabby , belated mourning carriage . There was a flapping of dingy white scarves as the dyed horses , with lowered heads , moved dejectedly away into the growing dusk , leaving a vision of rusty black clothes and of vague , drab faces gazing from the carriage - window on to the sombre , naked trees . [Mary]124-mary shuddered . ‘ [I]124-mary must get back , ’[124-mary] [she]124-mary thought , and calling a hansom , [she]124-mary was , in ten minutes , mounting the stairs again to [the sick room in [Portman Square]41-portman square]1448-the sick room in portman square . [Mary]124-mary hardly dared look when [she]124-mary reached [the bedroom]741-the bedroom again . [The sick girl , propped up on pillows]1450-the sick girl , propped up on pillows , was battling for life with [her]1450-the sick girl , propped up on pillows breath . The distended jugular veins told of the fearful struggle ; the lips were livid , the fingers clenched . The beautiful brown eyes were turned on [[her]1450-the sick girl , propped up on pillows mother]1709-her mother with the look of a tortured animal ; then [her]1450-the sick girl , propped up on pillows head fell forward , and [they]1452-they laid [her]1450-the sick girl , propped up on pillows length - wise on the bed . [Alison]128-alison lay long in a state of somnolence . In the silence of [the large bedroom]1453-the large bedroom , in which the only other sound was that of the sprightly French clock on the mantelpiece , ticking away the hours , [the sick woman]2980-the sick woman 's delirious mutterings seemed of fearful importance to [the watchers round the bed]1455-the watchers round the bed . What was [she]2980-the sick woman saying — [she]2980-the sick woman who was never to speak any more ? Long after , [Mary]124-mary remembered the last coherent words [she]124-mary had said : ‘ Will [my]124-mary feet get slim again when [I]124-mary am well ? ’[124-mary] The long night began . [Alison]128-alison still lay prone , but the breathing was now stertorous , with a kind of rattle in the throat . [Dr. Danby]238-dr. danby , summoned again by [Lady Jane]229-lady jane , implored [her]124-mary to be calm , for the end could not be long . But to [Mary]124-mary , during the endless hours of that December night , the end seemed long in coming . It tortured [her]124-mary to see [the one human being for whom [she]124-mary cared now in [the world]318-the world]1456-the one human being for whom she cared now in the world , dying that terrible death of suffocation . Towards midnight , the strain on [Mary]124-mary became intense . [Alison]128-alison fell into a doze , and then [Mary]124-mary crept , for a few moments , into [the next room]2345-the next room and threw open a window . The injustice of life revolted [her]124-mary . [Her]124-mary misery was too poignant for tears . When [she]124-mary was [a little child]1459-a little child [she]124-mary used to stiffen [herself]124-mary with silent rage when [any one]1844-any one accused or struck [her]124-mary unjustly . [The girl]1681-the girl felt something of that hardened feeling now . And so [Alison]128-alison , too , was to go . The last grim , speechless battle with annihilation was slowly being fought out in [that gay , beflowered bedroom]1462-that gay , beflowered bedroom . It was a still winter night , and a great round moon looked over the tops of [the tall houses]1463-the tall houses opposite , like a white , surprised face . The sounds of [the ponderous , buzzing city]1464-the ponderous , buzzing city entered in at the window with the whiff of fresh air ; the rattle of [cabs and omnibuses]1465-cabs and omnibuses ; voices of [the passers - by]1466-the passers - by . [Carriages]1467-carriages were driving round [the square]1468-the square ; [somebody]1469-somebody , two doors off , was giving a dinner - party . On the steps was [a little cluster of footmen]1470-a little cluster of footmen . Presently the hall door opened , there was a rush of light , and the figures of [two ladies , in white cloaks and laces]1471-two ladies , in white cloaks and laces , passed from under [the portico]2147-the portico . The click of the carriage door was audible , the word ‘ [Home]1741-home ! ’[1470-a little cluster of footmen] and the sound of retreating wheels . Presently [a couple of men]1473-a couple of men left , lighting [their]1473-a couple of men cigars as [they]1473-a couple of men went down [the steps]1474-the steps , and striding off on foot to the sounds of amused laughter . But presently [the square]1468-the square was silent . Not a branch stirred . Only the great white moon rose higher in the heavens with [her]1476-her cold , triumphant air . [Mary]124-mary sank on [her]124-mary knees at the open window , [her]124-mary forehead pressed against the sill . ‘ Why could it not have been [I]124-mary ? ’[124-mary] [she]124-mary moaned . ‘ [No one]2071-no one wants [me]124-mary , [no one]2071-no one cares for [me]124-mary ; while [Alison—. O God]245-god ! [O God]245-god ! and must [I]124-mary go on living — ? ’[124-mary] And then [she]124-mary remembered that [Death]266-death , [the great destroyer]1477-the great destroyer , had an irony which is all [his]266-death own . [Beautiful , noble , helpful lives]1478-beautiful , noble , helpful lives were crushed , destroyed , annihilated . [Death]266-death made no more account of [them]1479-they than [a schoolboy]1480-a schoolboy does of a beetle , on whom , in passing by , [he]1480-a schoolboy tramps wantonly in [a ditch]1481-a ditch . A minute ago [they]1479-they breathed , and hoped , and loved ; another minute in the æons of time , and the insect was a mere blotch of slime , [one 's passionately loved idol]1482-one 's passionately loved idol lay rotting under the sod . And for a little while , if [they]1479-they were lucky , [the idols]1483-the idols were remembered , but more often [their]1479-they memories , too , passed away . The burden of sex , the lust of life , the torture of the ideal , the unslaked thirst for immortality , had all been [theirs]1479-they ; but always [others]2714-others came to take [their]2714-others places , to suffer the same agonies , to be thrilled , for a brief moment , with the same fears and pleasures . And always the long procession moved on , and on , and on ; [some]3031-some fell out , but [others]2714-others jostled forward ; the ranks were filled up ; there was small time for tears . Yes , for ever [the great army of humanity]1487-the great army of humanity moved on , on its strange inexplicable march from [a mother]1751-a mother 's womb to six feet of oozing clay . The long hours of the night dragged slowly by . In [the sick room]2990-the sick room the only sounds were the ticking of the French clock and the terrible , ominous rattle from the lace - trimmed pillows . It was nearing dawn . Restless and hysterical with grief , [the mother]1816-the mother had run out to write one more vain summons to [the doctor]693-the doctor . Outside , there were [women]1964-women 's voices , sobbing on the stair - case . [Mary]124-mary sat by the bedside , waiting for the dawn , waiting for the dread inexorable moment . And then , just when there came creeping in behind the blind the wan , drabbish light of the December daybreak — of the morning which [Mary]124-mary remembered with a kind of stunned feeling ing was to be that of [Vincent Hemming]129-vincent 's marriage — a strange noise from the pillows made [her]124-mary heart stand still in [her]124-mary body . And suddenly [she]124-mary was aware that there was no sound at all in [the sick room]2990-the sick room but the pert click of the little gilt clock on the mantelpiece , ticking , ticking , ticking , glibly away . FIVE years had passed . All day long [the streets]276-the streets had been full of carriages going and coming from [Buckingham Palace]111-buckingham palace . The spring sunshine fell on the pink arms , the thin bare shoulders of [young girls on the back seats of broughams and closed barouches]1495-young girls on the back seats of broughams and closed barouches , which passed swiftly by , leaving a vision of a foam of tulle , [an excited young face]1496-an excited young face , a cascade of flowers , or the large complacent bosom of [a chaperon]1497-a chaperon . Some of [these carriages]1498-these carriages stopped , towards five o'clock , at [[Lady Jane Ives]131-lady jane ' in [Portman Square]41-portman square]3052-lady jane ives ' in portman square . [The drawing - room]2286-the drawing - room was already spread with [shining satin trains]3054-shining satin trains , and heavy with the odour of slightly faded hothouse flowers , before [the hostess]3055-the hostess [herself]3055-the hostess appeared , for [Lady Jane]131-lady jane was presenting [a niece]3056-a niece , and had been late in getting away from [the palace]3057-the palace . [One or two men]388-one or two men , vaguely bored , strayed about with uncertain feet among the yards of satin and brocade which covered the floor ; and [the women]1108-the women , in [their]1108-the women nodding plumes and foolish trains , seemed conscious of [their]1108-the women wrinkled throats and faded skins , as [they]1108-the women stood , with a somewhat forced smile , receiving the usual compliments . But very soon [Lady Jane]131-lady jane appeared , swimming into [the room]396-the room with [her]131-lady jane large smile , and [her]131-lady jane ruby velvet train , and having behind [her]131-lady jane [a young girl in white , with puffy pink cheeks and an alarmed air]3061-a young girl in white , with puffy pink cheeks and an alarmed air . ‘[131-lady jane] [[My]0-i niece]1499-my niece , [Victoria]267-victoria , ’ [she]0-i announced to [every one]3062-every one , in [her]0-i rapid , genial manner . ‘[131-lady jane] Presented today ; [[[my]0-i brother]1500-my brother 's girl]1501-my brother 's girl , [you]1502-you know . [Dear Victoria]267-victoria is so devoted to society ; [she]267-victoria is going to stay with [me]0-i . It will be quite charming . ’ And [Mr. Beaufort Flower]180-mr. beaufort flower , with a huge white button - hole which accentuated the dingy yellow of [his]180-mr. beaufort flower skin , and with several tell - tale wrinkles at the corners of [his]180-mr. beaufort flower eyes , murmured to [Mr. Bosanquet - Barry]179-mr. bosanquet - barry as [he]179-mr. bosanquet - barry gazed with half - closed lids at [the new candidate for society]3063-the new candidate for society 's favours ; — ‘[0-i] [I]0-i adore drawing - room teas . [One]1802-one sees so much of [people]1883-people , do n't [you]1502-you know . And in the daylight , too , [one]1802-one gets such a good idea of what [they]1883-people are really like , ’ [he]179-mr. bosanquet - barry tittered , turning to where [Lady Blaythewaite]160-lady blaythewaite 's creamy white shoulders were illuminated by the full glare from the window , the sunlight sparkling on the diamond tiara round [her]267-victoria forehead . ‘[1802-one] [She]267-victoria 's got [her]267-victoria best “ fender ” on , ’ said [Mr. Bosanquet - Barry]179-mr. bosanquet - barry , with rising interest , ‘[267-victoria] by [Jove]215-jove ! did [you]1502-you ever see such jewels ? And what a skin ! ALTHOUGH [she]124-mary had been thinking of [Hemming]129-vincent for hours , the sharp , agitated pull of the bell startled [Mary]124-mary as [she]124-mary sat sorting papers at [her]124-mary desk in [the little room]1960-the little room , [a third room , crowded with bookshelves , which [she]124-mary had been able to add to [her]124-mary domain]3147-a third room , crowded with bookshelves , which she had been able to add to her domain during the last year . ‘[129-vincent] [Mr. Vincent Hemming]129-vincent , ’ said [the servant]1894-the servant opening the door . [He]129-vincent got up presently , moving restlessly about [the little room]1960-the little room , examining with curious eyes [the place which was [[Mary]124-mary 's home]3152-mary 's home]3151-the place which was mary 's home . [Mary]124-mary had risen and walked to the window , where [she]124-mary stood fidgeting with the tassel of the blind , and looking down into [the dingy street]1572-the dingy street . Presently [he]1578-he left [the house]316-the house , and wandered along towards [Regent Street]1-regent street .
